INIS IRHIR, ISLAND, off the Barony of Kilmacrenan, Co. of Donegal, and Province of Ulster. INISKEA, ISLANDS, off the Barony of Erris, Co. of Mayo, and Province of Connaught. There are two Islands of this name, distinguished by their situation of North and South. INISKEEL, or, NAIRN, in the Barony of Boylagh and Bannogh, Co. of Donegal, and Provinceof Ulster: a II. and V., valued in the King's Books at _£15. sterling: a Church : a Glebe House, and a Glebe of above 40 acres : The Rev. John Barrett, the Incumbent (in 1806), Avho has cure of souls, is resident, and discharges the duties. Iniskeel is in the Diocese of Raphoe, and Province of Armagh. The Rectory ancl Vicarage have been consolidated from time imme morial, ancl form but one parish. Itis 135 m. N. W. from Dublin. It is situate upon the Sea Coast. It has three Post-days in the Aveek. t

I N I INISKEEL, ISLAND, off the Barony of Boylagh ancl Bannogh, Co. of Donegal, and Province of Ulster. — " St. Conald Coel Avas Abbot of Iniscoel, ancl is honoured here on the 12th of May ; St. Dalian wrote a work in his praise ; he was killed by pirates about the year 590, and was interred with his friend ; his Festival is holden on January the 29th. Here is a celebrated well, which, with the church, is dedicated to St. Conald, and yearlv visited by a great concourse of Pilgrims on the I2th of May."— ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 100. INISKELTAIR, ISLAND, off the Barony of Tullagh, Co. of Clare, and Province of Munster. It is situate in the River Shannon. — " St. Camin founded an Abbey here, Avhich Avas afteiAvards a Church, and still retains his name. He died in the year 653, and was buried in his oAvn church. His Feast is observed on the 25th of March. There yet remains here a fine Round tower, with seven small churches, which bespeak, in miniature, an elegance of taste. This Island is remarkable for the great resort of pilgrims on certain festivals." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 47. INISKENNY, Avithin the County of the City of Cork, ancl Province of Munster: a Prebend, valued in the King's Books at £2.. 5.. 0 sterling, and Epis eopally united, in 1768, to the R. and V. of Moviddy, the V. (Rectory Im propriate) of Kilbonane, and the V. (one Rectory Impropriate ; one other Rectory belongs to Kilbrogan,) of Aglish ; and Avith Avhich is .holden, . by Faculty, the R. of Templetrine: a Church, at Moviddy ; a Glebe House, at Mo viddy, and a Glebe, of 80 acres : a Glebe, (but no Glebe House) in Kilbonane, of 9 acres, adjoining the ruins of the church, and 5 miles distant from Moviddy : a Glebe, in Templetrine, of 19 acres, adjoining the ruins of a church : a Glebe, (but no Glebe House), in Aglish, of 5 acres, adjoining the site of the old church, and 5 miles distant from the church at Moviddy : no Glebe House, or Glebe, in Iniskenny : The Rev. Edward Kenney, the Prebendary (in 1806), who has cure of souls, is resident, and discharges the duties, assisted by his Curates, viz., by a Resident Curate at Moviddy, at an annual Salary of _£50. ; at Iniskenny, at<£l0. ; and of Templetrine, there being but one Protestant Family in the parish, at £5. Iniskenny is in the Diocese of Cork, and Province of Cashel. It is 4 m. S. W. from Cork. The parishes of Moviddy, Kilbonane, and Aglish, are contiguous ; their estimated extent being 4 miles in length, and from 3 to 4 miles in breadth. Iniskenny is 8 miles distant from Moviddy, and 10 miles from Templetrine ; Avhich is 5 miles distant from Moviddy. INIS KERACH, ISLAND, off the Barony of Erris, Co. of Mayo, and Prov ince of Connaught. INISKERRY, ISLAND, off the Barony of Ibrickin, Co. of Clare, and Prov ince of Munster. It is situate in the Atlantic Ocean, about three miles from the Mainland.—" St. Senan of Iniscathy, built an Abbey on Iniscaorach, in the terri tory of Hybreccain, in Thomond,"— ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 46. INISKIN, v. KENE.

I N I INISLIRE, ISLAND, off the Barony of Burishhoole, Co. of Mayo, and Prov ince of Connaught. It is situate in Clew Bay. INISLOUGH, v: INNISLOUNAGH. INISLUA, ISLAND, off the Barony of , Co. of Clare, and Provinceof Munster.—" St. Senan of Corea Baiscin founded a Monastery here before the coming of St. Patrick into Munster, and St. Moronoc, called The Penitentiary of Inisluaidhe, had a cell here at the time of St. Senan's death."— ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 48. INIS MAC KILANE, ISLAND, one of the Blasquets. INISMAGRATH, in the Barony of Dromahaire, Co. of Leitrim, and Province of Connaught: a V. : a Church, in good repair : no Glebe House; 541 acres of Glebe Avithin the parish, and part of it near the church : The Rev. John Leahy, the Incumbent (in 1806), who has cure of souls ; the duties are discharged by a Resident Curate, at a Salary of £60. per annum. Inismagrath is in the Diocese of Kilmore, ancl Province of Armagh. It is 5^ in. S. E. from Dromahaire. INISMAIN, ISLAND, off the Barony of Kilmain, Co. of Mayo, and Province of Connaught. It is situate in Lough Mask.—" There Avas an abbey on this Island, as Ave are informed by the author of the Life of St. Cormac, avIio lived in the year 490."— .ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 502. INIS MAKEERA ISLAND, off the Barony of Boylagh and Bannogh, Co. of Donegal, and Province of Ulster. INIS MANAN, ISLAND, off the Barony of Kilmacrenan, Co. of Donegal, and Province of Ulster. INIS MOCHDA, in the Barony of — -, Co. of Louth, and Province of Leinster. According to Mr. Archdall, this church A\*as destroyed four times by fire. INISMURRAY, ISLAND, off the Barony of Carbury, Co. of Sligo, and Prov ince of Connaught— " In the early ages, there Avas an Abbey here, dedicated to the Virgin Mary, and governed by St. Dicholla, the son of Meinida, Avho died A. D. 747.— This Island is a Rock rising from the Sea, Avith horrid precipices towards the Ocean, but shelving gently, like steps, on the side opposite the land. It contains about 130 acres ofa shallow soil, from four to five inches in depth, Avhich serves to feed some sheep, a few coavs, and five or six horses, the remainder of the island is a mere rock. The habitable part contains about 40 or 50 peoplej children included, avIio live in five houses, Avith as many barns adjoining them. They intermarry amongst each other, and Avhen the land is overstocked with inhabitants, they seek their fortunes on tbe great Island of Ireland. They are one community, and live by fishing and selling their fish on the Main. They speak Irish only, one man boAved beneath the Aveight of years excepted (in 1779): and boast their having had this island in possession upwards of seven hundred years. \\ hat is called the Abbey, is an inclosure of dry stones, from five to seven ancl eight feet thick. Itis impossible to determine whether it is round or oval; more rude, inelegant Avorkmanship Avas never seen. There are a few cells under ground,

I N I which receive their light, some through a hole at the top, others through a loop hole in the side ; they are dark, and horrible dungeons. There are also two Chapels built Avith mortar, and quite in a gross state, as is St. Molasse's Cell, which has a stone roof, and Avhere the statue of the Saint is preserved. One of the chapels, standing by itself, has an extraordinary Avindow, the arch of Avhich is one rough crooked stone, just in its original shape. Here is an altar, called the cursing altar, Avhich is covered with round stones, and North-West of this, stands the altar osthe Trinity. The neighbouring inhabitants say, that isa man, avIio is really wronged, turns one of these stones, and, at the same time, curses his adversary, tlie wish, Avhatsoever it is, will fall upon him if guilty, but if otherwise, the curse recoils upon the person Avho denounces it; this keeps them in such aAve, as to prevent rash imprecations. There are several small inclosures with a stone in the centre, and some springs, each of them consecrated to a particular saint. A statue of their Patron, Saint Molasse, very rudely carved in Avood, and painted of a redish colour, is still preserved here. The Abbey was erected conjointly by this Saint and St. Columb, but the latter being of an impetuous and fiery disposi tion could not accord Avith the mildness of Molasse, and betook himself to the Main-land, leaving the other in peaceable possession."— ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 634. INISNEGANANAGH, or, THE ISLAND OF CANONS, off the Barony of ~ , Co. of Clare, ancl Province of Munster.—" Donald O'Brien, King of Limerick, in the 12th century, founded, or rebuilt, a Priory here, for Canons Reg ular following the Rule of St. Augustine." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern, p. 48. INIS NI BROE, ISLAND, one of the Blasquets. INIS PATRICK, v. PATRICK'S, ST., ISLE. INISPICT, or, INISPUINC, off the Barony of Carbery, Co. of Cork, and Province of Munster. According to Mr. Archdall, a Monastery Avas- built here about the close of the Sixth century. INISPUINC, v. INISPICT. INISQUIN, off the Barony of Clare, Co. of Galavay, and Province of Con naught. An Island, situate in Lough Corrib " St. Brendan erected an Abbey here, and made St. Meldan, one of his disciples, Abbot. St. Meldan died some time before tbe year 626, his Festival is holden on the 7th of February."—Arch daWs Monast. Hibern. p. 288. INIS ROCHA, in tlie great Lough Erne, Co. of Fermanagh, and Province of Ulster.—" About the beginning* of tbe Sixth century, St. Berchan, the son of Declan, son of Fieg, son of Deodatus, son of Rochad, son of Colla Dachriocb, was Abbot here; Avhere his Festival is holden on the 24th of November."—Arch daWs Monast. Hibern. p. 263. INIS SAMER, ISLAND, off the Barony of Tyrhugh, Co. of Donegal, and Province of Ulster. — " An Island in the Bay of Donegal, at the mouth of the

I N I River Erne. There seems to have been a Religious house on this Island, for Ave fio*d that Flaherty O'Maoldora, King of Conall, or Tyrconell, Inisoen, and of the districts of Easdara and Loughgille, having renounced the cares of the world, and dedicated himself to heaven, died in this Island in the year 1 197."— ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 100. INIS SHARK, ISLAND, off the Barony of Ballinahinch, Co. of Galway, and Province of Connaught. INIS-SHERE, ISLAND, off the Barony of Ballinahinch, Co. of Galway, and Province of Connaught. INIS STORMOR, ISLAND, off the Barony of Tirawly, Co. of Mayo, and Province of Connaught.— According to Mr. Archdall, there Avas a Monastery here, for Eremites of the order of St. Augustin, under the Invocation of the Holy Trinity. INISTEGILL, ISLAND, off the Barony of Morisk, Co. of Mayo, and Prov ince of Connaught. It is situate near the entrance of The Killery Harbour. INISTIOGE, in the Barony of Gowran, Co. of Kilkenny, and Provinceof Leinster: a V., Episeopally united, in 1782, to the Vicarages of Kilbeacon, Killahy, and Rosinan, and the Prebend of Cloneamery : a Church, in good repair, in tbe parish of Inistioge : no Glebe House, but the Incumbent is under orders to build : a Glebe, of 16 acres, in the parish of Kilbeacon, contiguous to the old church there: Tbe Rev. Francis W. Flood, the Vicar (in 1806), Avho has cureof souls in all parts of the Union, is resident, and discharges the duties in person, as sisted by a Curate. Inistioge is in the Diocese of Ossory and Province of Dublin. It is 63 m. S. S. W. from Dublin. It has six Post-days in the week. The Fairs are holden on the 9th of June, ancl 1 3th and 14th of December. It is situate upon the navigable River Nore. Near this is Woodstock, the superb Mansion of William Tighe, Esq. The parishes in the Union of Inistioge are contiguous to each other : the estimated extent of each parish being about two miles.—" An Abbey appears to have been founded here, so early as the year 800: But about A. D. 1210, Thomas, the son of Anthony, seneschal of Leinster, erected an Abbey here for Augustinian Canons, and dedicated it to the Virgin Mary and St. Columb, the especial Patrons of the place. By the advice of the Bishop of Ossory, he appoint ed Alured, a Canon of Kells, the first Prior, and granted to him and the Convent, the Churches of Grenan, ancl Kilcrenath."— ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 359. INISTRAVAN, ISLAND, off the Barony of Moycullin, Co. of Galway, and Province of Connaught. INISTUISKAR, ISLAND, off the Barony of Corcaguinny, Co. of Kerry, and Province of Munster. INISTURC, ISLAND, off the Barony of Morisk, Co. of Mayo, and Province of Connaught. INIS VACHTUIR, in the Barony of Half Fowre, Co. of West Meath, and

I N N Province of Leinster. It is situate in Lough Shelan. According to Mr. Archdall, St. Carthag built an Abbey on this Island about the year 540, who, a little after that period, was Abbot here. INNISCALTHRA, in the Barony of Leitrim, Co. of Galway, and Province of Connaught: a V., valued in the King's Books at £0..6. .8 sterling, and Episeo pally united, on the 26th of August 1803, to the Vicarages of Clonrush, Moynoe, and Ogonilloe : a Church, in good repair, in the parish of Inniscalthra: no Glebe House, or Glebe Land : The Rev. Richaid Martin, A. B., the Incumbent (in 1806), who has cure of souls, is resident at Killaloe, by permission, being Registerer of the Dioce'ses of Killaloe and Kilfenora, ancl discharges the duties : These parishes collectively are too small, making but ,£58. per annum. Inniscalthra is in the Diocese of Killaloe, and Province of Cashel. It is 8 m. N. b. W. from Killaloe. The parishes in the Union of Inniscalthra are contiguous; tlieir estimated extent from North to South being 4 miles, and from East to West 3 miles. It is situate upon the River Shannon. INNISCALTHRA, ISLAND, off the Barony of Leitrim, Co. of Galway, and Province of Connaught. It is situate in the River Shannon. INNISCATHRIE, ISLAND, off the Barony of Moyferta, Co. of Clare, and Province of Munster : a Prebend, to Avhich belong, as the Corps thereof, the Rectory of Kilfieragh, and Kilrush, valued in the King's Books at £4. sterling; and with Avhich are holden, Episeopally united, on the 24th of July 1777, the Vicarages of Kilfieragh, Kilballyhone, Killard, and Moyferta: two Churches, in good repair; one of them being in the parish of Kilrush, and the other in the parish of Kilfieragh: a Glebe House, building, in the parish of Kilrush: three Glebes; one, of 2 a. 3r. 5 p., in the parish of Kilrush, within a quarter of a mile of the church; another, of 3 a. 2r. 25 p., in the parish of Kilfieragh, convenient to the church ; and the third, of 3 a. 0 r. 20 p., in the parish of Moyferta, con venient to the site osthe old church there : The Rev. Irvine Whitty, A. M., the Prebendary (in 1806), who has cure of souls, is resident, and discharges the duties, assisted by his Resident Curate, The Rev. John Graham, A. B. Inniscathrie is in the Diocese of Killaloe, and Province of Cashel. It is 2 m. S. b. W. from Kilrush. The rich and beautiful little Island of Inniscathrie is situate at the entrance of the River Shannon, between tbe Counties of Kerry, and Clare. The parishes in the Union of Inniscathrie are contiguous ; their estimated extent, from North to South, being 12 miles, and from East to West 8 miles. According to the Ecclesiastical Report, each of these parishes, separately, is too small to afford the means of comfort to a Resident Incumbent.—" St. Senan of Corea Baiscin found ed an Abbey here before the arrival of St. Patrick in Munster, as some report : but others say, that St Patrick himself Avas the founder, and that he placed St. Senan here : he had eleven churches for his monks, and no women were permitted to land on the island before the coming of the Danes into this country. The Prelates

I N N of this noble and ancient church are sometimes called by our Ecclesiastical His torians, Bishops, and at other times, Abbots : in process of time it became a Priory of Regular Canons. The monument of St. Senan is still to be seen here, with the remains of eleven small churches and several cells ; in the stone that closes the top of the altar windoAV of the great church is the head of the Saint, with his mitre, boldly executed, and but little defaced. An ancient Round tower of 120 feet in height, and in complete repair, graces the scene. This island is remarkable for the resort of pilgrims on certain Festivals."— ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. pp. 49 et seq. INNISDADROM, in tbe Barony of Upper Ormond, Co. of Tipperary, and Province of Munster : a R. and V., being one of the parishes which constitute the Corps of the Precentorship of Killaloe : no Church: The Rev. William Had lock, A.B., Curate, in 1806. Innisdadrom is in the Diocese of Killaloe, and Province of Cashel. See, Lateragh. INNISFALLEN, ISLAND, in the Barony of Magunihy, Co. of Kerry, and Province of Munster. This Island contains twelve acres of land, and is situate in the Lake of Killarney.— " St. Finian Lobhar, or The Leper, son of Alild, King of Munster, and disciple of St. Brendan, sounded an Abbey here towards the close of the Sixth century. The remains of this abbey are very extensive, and its situation is extremely picturesque. A small chapel standing at some distance from the abbey, and which had originally belonged to it, is noAv converted by the Noble proprietor into a banqueting house for the reception of visitors to the romantic scenes of Killarney." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 301. INNISHARGY, in the Barony of Ardes, Co. of Doavn, ancl Province of Ulster: a V., united by Act of Parliament of an old date, to the Vicarages of St. Andre av's, Ballyhalbert, ancl Ballywalter. Innishargy is in the Diocese of Down, and Province of Armagh. This parish contains 1920 acres of land. See, St, Andrew's. INNISKEAN, in the Barony of Carbery, Co. of Cork, and Province of Mun ster. It is 7 m. W. S. W. from Bandon bridge. It is situate upon tbe River Bandon. INNISKEEN, in the Barony of Donaghmoyne, Co. of Monaghan, and Prov ince of Ulster: a R. and V. : a Church, in good condition: a Glebe House; 35 acres of Glebe, very near the church: The Hon. and Rev. George Gore, the In cumbent (in 1806), avIio has cure of souls, is resident, and discharges tbe duties. Inniskeen is in the Diocese of Clogher, and Province of Armagh. It is 3| m. N. from Louth. It is situate on the River Fane. INNISKILLEN, or, ENNISKILLEN. INNISLOUNAGH, partly in the Barony of Ufa and Off a, Co. of Tipperary, and partly in the Barony of Glanehiry, Co. of Waterford, and Province of Munster : an entire Rectory, Episeopally united, in the year 1804, to the entire

1 1 N N Rectory of Monks Land, Avhen the present Incumbent took possession; and it appears, that it has been holden so united, time out of mind : a Church, in repair, on the Tipperary side osthe parish of Innislounagh : no Glebe House, or Glebe : The Rev. George Fleury, the Incumbent (in 1806), avIio has cure of souls, and resides on his Archdeaconry in the City of Waterford : the duties are performed by a Curate, who resides within a mile of the church, in an adjacent parish, at a Salary of £75. per annum. Innislounagh is in the Diocese of Lismore, and Prov ince of Cashel. It is 2j m. W. S. W. from Clonmell. It is situate upon the River Suir, by Avhich it is divided into two parts. The parishes in the Union of Innis lounagh are not contiguous ; and are at least twenty-three miles separate. Ac cording to the Ecclesiastical Report, the entire Rectory of Innislounagh might very Avell stand alone ; and Glebe land ought (if possible), to be purchased near the church, and a Glebe House built thereon. — "St. Mochoemoc, or The Beauti ful, founded an Abbey at Inisleambnacta, which he dedicated to the Virgin Mary, and died on the 13th of March 655 ; — This Avas a singularly beautiful building, in which Avas a Chapel, said to have been consecrated by St. Patrick. There is also a celebrated well here, which, as we are told, Avrought many miracles, particularly in removing distempers. The learned Nicholas Fagan, Abbot of Inislaughnaght, provided by the Pope to the See of Waterford, Avas interred here in 16 1 7." — Arch daWs Monast. Hibern. pp. 66 1 . et seq. INN IS MAC SAINT, in the Barony of Magheraboy, Co. of Fermanagh, and Province of Ulster : a R, and V., valued in the King's Books at <£20. sterling : three Churches ; one, in good condition : the other two, under repair : a Glebe House; 540 acres of Glebe, not distant from the churches: Thomas Brooke Clarke, D. D., the Incumbent (in 1806), Avho has cure of souls, and being Chaplain to His Royal Highness the Prince of Wales, is not resident ; the duties are dis- charged by tAvo Resident Curates. Innis Mac Saint is in the Diocese of Clogher, and Province of Armagh. It is adjacent to Church Hill, on the North West. It is situate on Lough Erne. — " St. Nenn, or Nernid, osthe blood Royal of Ireland, Avho Avas educated under St. Fiech at Sletty, and afterwards under St. Finian at Clonard, founded this famous Abbey (on an Islancl, in Lough Erne, about half a mile from the shore), and died in the year 523 or 530. His Festival is commem- orated here on the 18th of January. The Saint's Bell, ornamented with gold and silver, is yet preserved here as a precious relique, and is holden in so great venera- tion amongst the loAver class of people, that it is often judicially tendered them to sAvear on. This ancient abbey, in process of time, Avas converted into a parish church, Avith a very large district, being a Rectory and Vicarage, in the Diocese of Clogher ; but the situation being at length found to be highly inconvenient, it Avas in the reign of Queen Anne removed to Drumenagh, in the same parish, on the Main-land."— ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 262. INNISMOOTHY, in the Barony of Slane, Co. of Meath, and Province of 2 z

I N V Leinster : a R. and V., endowed with <£l0. Income: no Church: no Glebe House, or Glebe : The Rev. Valentine Duke, the Incumbent (in 1806), who has cure of souls, ancl is non-resident, on account of his infirmities : the duties are discharged by the Curate of Drumcondra. Innismoothy is in the Diocese of Meath, and Prov ince of Armagh. It is 4 m. W. S. W. from Ardee. The last collation of this Benefice was to the Curate of Drumcondra : the Income is scarcely ,£30. per annum. INNISMORE, ISLAND, in the Barony of Carbury, Co. of Sligo, and Prov ince of Connaught. It is situate in Lough Gille, to the South East of Sligo. — " St. Loman founded the Church of Innismore in the time of St. Columb.— This Island, commonly called^ Church Island, is about tAvo miles in length, and in some places half a mile in breadth. The church stands at the East end of the island, and in former ages it was the Burial-place of the parish of Calry. In a rock, near the door of the church, is a cavity, called Our Lady's Bed, which is said to be favourable to Avomen in pregnancy, who fondly imagine, that, by going into it and turning thrice round, at the same time saying certain prayers, they shall not die in labour. This rock, and the remains of the church, are noAv entirely covered with ivy." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 633. INNISMOTT, v. INNISMOOTHY. INNISTYMON, or, ENNISTIMOND, in the Barony of Corcomroe, Co. of Clare, and Province of Munster. It is H85 m. W, S. W. from Dublin. It has six Post-days in the week. The Castle is the handsome Seat of EdAvard O'Brien, Esq.—" St Luchtighern Avas Abbot of Inistimensis, or Inistornensis."— ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 52. INOSH, ISLAND, off the Barony of Bunratty, Co. of Clare, and Province of Munster. It is situate in the River Shannon. INSHEY, in the Barony of Corcaguinny, Co. of Kerry, and Province of Munster : an entire Rectory, being one of the parishes which constitute the Union of Ballinvoher. Inshey is in the Diocese of Ardfert and Aghadoe, and Province of Cashel. See, Ballinvoher. INSHIANLY, v. INCHYANLY. IN VER, in the Barony of Belfast, Co. of Antrim, and Province of Ulster : a R., or Perpetual Cure, being one of the five parishes which constitute the Deanery of Connor : no Church : no Glebe House, or Glebe : The Rev. John Dobbs, the Resident Curate, in 1806, at a Salary of £75. per annum. In ver is in the Diocese of Connor, and Province of Armagh. It is adjacent to Larne, on the South. This parish contains 1220, acres of land. See, Carrickfergus. IN VER, in the Barony of Erris, Co. of Mayo, and Province of Connaught. A village, situate on Broad Haven, on the Western Ocean. INVER, alias INVERNAYLE, in the Barony of Boylagh and Bannogh, Co. of Donegal, and Province of Ulster: a R. and V., being the Corps of the 2

IRR Prebend thereof, Avhich is valued in the King's Books at ,£10. sterling; and "with Avhich is holden, by Faculty, the Rectory and Vicarage of Templecrone : a Church : a Glebe House, and a Glebe of above 40 acres: The Rev. Alexander Montgomery, the Incumbent (in 1806), who has cure of souls, is resident, and discharges the duties in person. Inver is in the Diocese of Raphoe, and Province of Armagh. The Rectory and Vicarage have been consolidated from time immemorial, and form but a single parish. It is 8 m. W. from Donegal. It is situate upon the River Inver, at the bottom of Inver Bay.—" St Natalis, who died A. D. 563, Avas Abbot of Inbemaile. A small Monastery Avas founded here, in the 15th century, for Friars of the third order of St. Francis, and probably on the very site of the ancient Abbey of St. Natalis."— ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 99- IRELAND'S EYE, off the Barony of Coolock, Co. of Dublin, and Province of Leinster. It is a small Island, situate in the Irish Sea, about a mile from the Main-land. It produces many curious medicinal plants. It Avas anciently called Adro's, by Ptolomey Adri-descrta, by Pliny Andros, and by Richard of Cirencester Edria. — " St. Nessan founded an Abbey here about A. D. 570, where he passed the evening of a well-spent life in fasting and in prayer. The Book osthe four Gospels, commonly called The Garland of Hoxvth, was preserved here, of which Archbishop Allen, in the Liber Niger, says, ' That book is holden in so much esteem aud A-eneration, that good men scarcely dare take an oath on it, for fear of the judgments of God being immediately shewn on those Avho should forswear themseh-es.' The ruins of St. Nessan's church still remain on the South side of the Island."— ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 221. IRISH-TOWN, v. CANICE, ST. IRISH-TOWN, in the Barony of Half RathdoAvn, Co, of Dublin, and Prov ince of Leinster. It is 1|- m. E, from Dublin. It is a decayed village, situate upon Dublin Bay. IRRELAGH, or, MUCRUSS, in the Barony of Magunihy, Co. of Kerry, and Province of Munster. It is situate on the borders of Lough Lane.—" Donald, son of Thady Mac Carthy, in the year 1440, founded a Friary here, under the Invo cation of the Holy Trinity, for Conventual Franciscans : He repaired it in the year 1468, a feAV months before his decease. Irrelagh has continued since that time the cemetery of the Mac Carthy family. And Donald, Earl of Clancare, was interred here; as Avas Patrick, Lord Kerry, the Earl's nephe aa% who died on the 12th of August 1600. This Abbey was re-edified by the Roman Catholicks in the year 1602, but Avas soon after permitted to go to ruin. It is surrounded by a venerable grove of very tall ash-trees, Avhich in some places grow spontaneously from the ruins. The choir, nave, and steeple, are yet entire, as are the cloisters, which consist of several Gothic arches all of solid marble, inclosing a small square, in the centre of Avhich stands a very tall yeAV-tree, Avhose spreading branches, over shadowing and throAving a broAvn shade over the niches of the Avhole cloister, form

I S L a much more solemn ancl awful kind of covering than the original one. The steeple of this extensive building is supported by a Gothic arch, which, from its size could only contain one bell. A miraculous image of the Virgin Mary Avas said to have been preserved here. This abbey, Avith its possessions, Avere granted to Robert Collan."— ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 303. ISERKELLY, or, DYSERT-KELLY, in the Barony of Loughrea, Co. of Galway, and Province of Connaught: a V., valued in the King's Books at <£l. sterling, being one of the parishes which constitute the Union of Killinane. ISLAND OF ALL SAINTS, in the Barony of Rathline, Co. of Longford, and Province of Leinster. It is situate in Lough Ree.—" Here St. Kieran built a noble Monastery in the year 544. In four years afterwards he procured a very large endowment for the support of its poor; and having appointed St. Domnan, or more properly Donnan, to be his successor, he forsook this Island, and erected the Abbey of Clonmacnoise, In 1087, it Avas spoiled by the Munstermen. We are told tbat a descendant of Sir Henry Dillon of Drumrany (who came into Ireland Avith John Earl of Morton) erected an Abbey on this Island, and probably on the site of the ancient Abbey of St. Kieran. It was granted at the suppression to Sir Patrick Barnwall." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p., 441. KELLS, in the Barony of Kells, Co. of Kilkenny, ancl Province of Leinster : a V., united, by an authority unknown, to the Rectories ancl Vicarages of Ballytobin, Earlstown, and MallardstOAvn, and the Rectories of Aghnamolt, Kilrea, and Sta macarty : a Church, in good repair, in the parish of Kells : a Glebe House, in good repair, in the parish of Kells : a Glebe, of 21 acres, at Kells, near the church ; and also 15 acres of Glebe, which lie scattered in different parts of the union, and are not convenient to the site of any church : The Rev. The parishes in the Union of Kells are all contiguous to each other ; tlieir estimated extent being about 3 miles in breadth, and about 4 miles in length.—" Geoffrey, the Son of Robert, on his coming into Ireland, obtained in possession the Barony of Kells, Avhere, by advice of Richard Earl of Strigul, his Patron, he founded a Priory, in the year 1193, Avhich he dedicated to the Blessed Virgin ; and as there were not any Regular Canons of St. Augustin, osthe English nation, then in this Kingdom, he caused the church to be served by Priests, till he had procured the following persons from the Priory of Bodmin in Cornwall, viz., Reginald de Aclond, Hugh de Rous, Alured, and Algar : Reginald Avas the first Prior of this house, Avho was succeeded by Hugh ; Alured was made the first Prior of Inistioge; and Algar being sent to Rome on business respecting the priory, he obtained a Bishoprick in Lombardy. The Prior of Kells was a Lord of Parliament"— ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 361. KELLS, in the Barony of Kells, Co. of Meath, and Province of Leinster : aR., united, time out of mind, to the Chapelries of Burry, Duleen, and Rathboyne, and forming the Corps of the Archdeaconry of Meath, which is valued in the King's Books at ,£100. Irish Money: a Church, in perfect repair, in the parish and to Avn of Kells : a Glebe House, with all necessary offices, in perfect repair, 3 A

K E L on the Mensal lands in the parish of Kells; a Glebe, of 882 acres ; 80 acres of Avhich, Avhereon the house stands, are a quarter of a mile from the church ; 140 acres, three quarters of a mile from the church ; 256 acres, one mile and an half; 268 acres, three miles ; 132 acres, half a mile ; 3 acres, one mile and three quarters ; and 3 acres, two miles and an half: The Rev. Thomas de Lacy, the Incumbent (in 1806), who has cure of souls, is resident, and discharges the duties, assisted by two Curates. Kells is in the Diocese of Meath, ancl Province of Armagh. It is 31| m. N. W. from Dublin. The Fairs are holden on the Thursday before Shrove Tuesday, the day before Ascension, 9th of September, and loth of October. It gives title of Viscount to the family of Cholmondeley. It is governed by a Sov ereign, and Deputy. Near it is Headfort, the magnificent Seat of The Marquess of Headfort. It is situate on the River Blackwater. It has six Post-days in the week. The parishes in the Union of Kells $ire contiguous ; that of Kells contain ing 3200 acres of land.— " In former ages this Avas a city of note, and on the arrival of the English, it was walled and fortified with to Avers: in 1 178, a castle Avas erected where the Market-place is noAv, and opposite the castle Avas a cross of an entire stone, ornamented with figures in bas relief, and many curious inscriptions in the ancient Irish character; within a small distance was the church of St. Senan, and on the South of the cemetery, Ave find a Round tower, Avhich measures 99 feet from the ground, the roof ending in a point, and near the top were four Avindows oppo site the Cardinal points. The celebrated Monastery of Regular Canons, founded in this town, about the year 550, and dedicated to the Virgin Mary, owes its origin to St. Columba, or Columb, to whom the site osthe abbey Avas granted by Dermod, the son of Kervaill, King of Ireland. — A Priory or Hospital, under the Invoca tion of St. John the Baptist, was founded in this town, by Walter de Lacie, Lord of Meath, in the reign of King Richard the First, for Cross-bearers or Crouched Friars, folloAving the Rule of St. Augustine. — There Avas also a Perpetual Chantry of three Priests or Chaplains in the parish church of St. Columb." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 541. KELLYSTOWN, in the Barony of Catherlogh, Co. of Carlow, ancl Province of Leinster : a R. : no Church, but one about to be built ; a Glebe House, newly erected ; four Glebes, not contiguous : the first, containing 3 a. 2 r. 23 p., on Avhich the Glebe House stands, being a mile and a half distant from the old church; the second, containing 10 a. 3 r. 4 p., being at the distance of 172 perches from the first; the third, containing 3 acres, near the old church; and the fourth, contain ing 3a. KENMARE, in tbe Barony of Glanerought, Co. of Kerry, and Province of Munster : a R. and V., Episeopally united to the Rectories and Vicarages of Kill crohane, and Templenoe, and the entire Rectory of Tuosist ; these parishes are in the Patronage of the CroAvn; and have been holden together since 1763: before 1763, Kenmare and Tuosist Avere holden by one Incumbent, and Templenoe and Killcrohane by another: a Church, in Kenmare, in good repair: no Glebe House, but one is about to be built at Kenmare : a Glebe, in Kenmare, of 4 a. K I L Carthuigh, the Great, Prince of Desmond, in the year 1465. He was murdered by Owen his brother, and Avas buried here in the middle of the choir : on his tomb is a Latin Inscription. A great part of this building still remains, Avith the nave and choir of the church. On the South side of the nave is an handsome ar cade of three Gothic arches, supported by marble columns, more massive than those of the Tuscan Order. This arcade continues to form one side of a chapel, being a cross aisle. In the choir are some old tombs of the family of Clancarty, &c. From the gateway, on either side, to the high road, are high banks entirely formed of human bones and sculls, which are cemented together Avith moss ; besides these, and great num bers strown about, there are several thousands piled up in the arches, windows, &c. The Bishop has not thought proper to call the Dean to the exercise of his dutv, on account of his great age and infirmities. The other Members of the Cathedral are represented by a Canon, Avho resides at present in the tOAvn, and performs duty for them all. The Revenues of the church, though inconsiderable, are faithfully employed in keeping the choir in good repair : but the nave has been long in ruins. The Bishop of Kildare (who is ahvays Dean of Christ. Church, in Dublin) has no Re sidence in his Diocese. There is extant in the Registry a Map of lands, belonging 1

K I L to the Bishoprick, in which seven fields (viz, No. 1, 2, 5, 6, 7,), are marked Mensal Lands, and contain 67 acres and 1 rood ; but, by a modern admeasurement, the same fields have been found to contain, of Plantation measure, 72 acres and 3 roods. In tbe above-mentioned old map, a field, adjoining the Cathedral precincts, or church-yard, is distinguished by being intituled, The Palace, and it is there stated to contain 3 acres ancl 2 roods ; but, by the modern admeasurement, it is no more than 3 acres. These lands were formerly, and still are intersected by roads, and there have been no traces knoAvn of The Palace in the memory of the oldest inhabitant of the town, in 1806. The Bishop of the Diocese has not the poAver, by Virtue of any existing law, to charge upon his successors any sum adequate to the building of a palace, by reason osthe Tenuity osthe Bishoprick. Kildare is in the Diocese of Kildare, and Province of Dublin. It is 24f m. S. W. from Dublin. It has six Post-days in the Av-eek. The Fairs are holden on the 12th of February, 26th of April, 12th of May, ancl 19th of September. It was instituted a Borough, in the reign of King James the First, and is governed by a Sovereign, tAvo Portrieves, and a ToAvn Clerk. It gave title of Earl to the noble family of Fitzgerald, until the year 1766, Avhen the then Earl was created Duke of Leinster. Of the original church, ancl city, of Kildare, there are at present no remains ; both the church, and other buildings, having been frequently plundered, and destroyed by the Danes. Tbe present toAvn, which seems to be situate Eastward of the ancient one, stands boldly on a rising ground, and con- sists of the Cathedral," part of the Castle which is inhabited, the County Infirmary, the Parish School adjoining the church, a Roman Catholic Chapel, a Market House, ancl about 180 houses, most of Avhich, however, are but indifferent. The Curragh of Kildare contains near 5000 English acres, and is under the superin- tendency of a Ranger. It is the Nexvmarket of Ireland, and generally allowed to exceed the English race-ground in elasticity of turf, and in characteristic beauty; the Meetings are holden on the last Aveek in April, the second Monday in June, and the second Monday in September, Avhen King's Plates are run for by Irish bred horses. The Bishoprick of Kildare, Avhich is valued in the King's Books at £69. A 1..4 Irish Money, was founded, according to Dr. Beaufort, about the end of the Fifth century. Its greatest length, from East to West, does not exceed 36 miles, nor its greatest breadth 23 miles. This See comprehends part osthe Counties of Kildare, the King's County, ancl the Queen's County. — "St. Brigid, the illegit- imate daughter of an Irish chieftain, Avas born in the year 453, and in the 14th year of her age she received the veil from the hands of St Patrick himself, or from one of his immediate disciples; it is said she made a pilgrimage to the Abbey of Glas tonbury, in Somersetshire. She founded a Nunnery here, before the year 484 ; and about the same time an Abbey was also founded under the same roof for monks, but separated by walls from the nunnery ; it afterwards came into possession of the Regular Canons of St. Augustine. The Nuns and Monks had but one church,

K I L in common, Avhich they entered at different doors. St Brigid presided as well over the Monks, as Nuns, and, strange to tell ! the Abbot of this House was subject to the Abbess for several years after the death of the celebrated founder, Avhich happened in the year 523, on the first of February, Avhen her Feast is celebrated. She Avas interred here, but her remains Avere afterwards removed to the Cathedral Church of DoAvn. — Gray Abbey is situated on the South side of the toAvn ; this monastery Avas erected for Friars of the Franciscan Order, or, as they Avere more generally called, Gray Friars, in the year 1260, by the Lord William de Vescy ; but the building Avas completed by Gerald Fitz-Maurice, Lord Offaley. A consid erable part of this abbey still remains ; which, from the appearance of the ruius, Avas of very small extent. — An House for Carmelites, or White Friars, was founded in this toAvn in the year 1290, by William de Vescy. Several Chapters of this Order were holden in Atherdee and in Dublin by David O'Buge, who was born in this town, and was a man of sound erudition, as such, he was in the highest estimation at Oxford and at Treves in Germany, and Avrote several learned works. He was well versed in Divinity, Philosophy, Rhetorick, and the Canon and Civil laAV, and Avas generally called the burning Light, the Mirror, and the Ornament of his country. O'Buge flourished about the year 1320, when he Avas Provincial of the Carmelite Order, and died full of years, and full of honour in this friary, where he was interred." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. pp. 322. et seq. KILDAREIS, in the Barony of , Co. of Leitrim, and Province of Con naught. — " Kildareis, or the Cell of, The two palms of the hands. KILKENNY, within the County osthe City of Kilkenny, and Province of Leins%er *. a City, in which are the following parishes, viz., St. Mary's, a R. and V., the Vicarage being valued in the King's Books at c£2..13..4 Irish Money : a Church, in very good repair: no Gleb House, or Glebe Land : The Rev. K I L St. Patrick's, a R. and V., being the Corps osthe Deanery of Ossory in the King's Patents (the parish of St. Patrick partly in the City of Kilkenny, and the Rectory of Aghaboe without cure of souls, being speci fied), Avhich is valued in the King's Books at £26.. 13. .4 Irish Money : no Church : The Glebe House, called The Deanery, is situate in the parish of St. Canice : there are about 20 acres of Glebe land, Avhich being within the Precincts of the Corporation, have from time immemorial been let off on building leases : The Hon. and Rev. Jos. Bourke, the Dean (in 1806), who has cure of souls in the parish of St. Patrick only, is resident in the Deanery House, and discharges the duties in person, assisted by his Curate, at a Salary of _£20. per annum. The parish of St. Patrick con- tains about 2200 acres of land. Kilkenny is in the Diocese of Ossory, and Province of Dublin. It is 57\ m. S. W. from Dublin. It has six Post-days in the week. The Markets are holden on Wednesday, and Saturday ; Ancl tbe Fairs on the 5th and 28th of March, Thursday after Trinity Sunday, 17th of August, 12th of September, llth of October, and 9th of November. This city sends one Member to Parliament. It is governed by a Mayor, Deputy, tAvo Sheriffs, a Recorder, and Town Clerk. Here is a Charter School, which was opened in the year 1745, for 70 Boys. This City came by marriage into the ancient family of Le Despencer. It was incorporated by Charter, from King James the First, in 1609. It surrendered \o Oliver Cromwell, in 1 650. It giA-es title of Earl to the family of Butler. The City of Kilkenny, and the Borough of St. Canice, or Irish-Town, according to Dr. Beaufort, form but one large town, Avhich stands in the midst of The County of the City of Kilkenny. It is delightfully situate on the River Nore, over Avhich are two handsome bridges. Of the many large and good buildings that adorn this city, I shall only mention the Bishop's Palace, the magnificent Castle of the Earl of Ormond, ancl the cele brated Free School or College, founded by the Butler family, and lately re-built on a large scale. The houses are decorated with a very beautiful black and Avhite marble, from the large Quarries in the neighbourhood of this city, which supply various parts of Ireland, and even London, Avith this commodity. Kilkenny con tains about 16,00 souls: and has been long noted for the politeness of its inhabit ants. In this city, and its environs, abundance of blankets and much coarse Avoollen cloth are manufactured. See, St. Canice.—" No Religious House appears to have been in this city, till after the year 1211, Avhen William Mareschal the elder, Earl of Pembroke, founded, on the East side of the town, ancl near the head of the small bridge, the Priory of St. John the Evangelist, for the relief of indigent poor. This monastery (Avith various possessions) was granted to the Mayor and Citizens of Kilkenny. The ruins of this building still remain in St. 4

K I L John Street.— The Franciscan Friary Avas founded (on the banks of the Nore) for Conventual Franciscans : And Richard Mareschal, Earl of Pembroke, is by some Avriters made the Founder. Near the Infirmary of the monastery is a well, Avhich was dedicated to St. Francis : it Avas formerly celebrated for many miracles said to have been Avrought there, and still retains some degree of credit amongst the superstitious. This building, with its offices, Avas of great extent, reaching from the street and city Avails to the river; and the ruins, Avhich still remain, sufficiently evince its former elegance and grandeur." — ArchdaWs Manast. Hibern. pp. 368. et se^. KILKENNY, WEST, in the Barony of Kilkenny West, Co. of West Meath, and Province of Leinster: a R. : a Church, in good repair: no Glebe House, or Glebe: The Rev. D. 773. A Priory or Hospital was afterwards erected in this town for Cross-bearers, or Crouched Friars, under the Invocation of St. John the Baptist Some writers erroneously give the foundation to the family of Tyrrell ; but, from the best authority, Ave say, that Friar Thomas, a Priest, and grandson of Sir Thomas Dillon, Avho came into Ireland, A. D. 1185, Avas the sounder of this house, and lies interred here. There Avas an Holy Well here, dedi cated to the Virgin Mary." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 720. The Prior of this House was a Lord of Parliament ; but, on account of the very great distance between his place of residence and the metropolis, he Avas seldom summoned. The walls of the church are of a great length, and strong in proportion ; these, ancl a noble Gothic East Avindow, are yet entire. The architecture, Avhich is of a dark marble, bespeaks the structure to be much more modern than the time before mentioned. Lar_re possessions, situate in clivers parts of the country, did belong to this House : which were granted for the term of 21 years to Thomas Clinton, at the annual rent of ,£17. .1.. 9.— An Augustinian Friary was said by some Avriters to haA-e been sounded here."— ArchdaWs Monast. KILLALA, in the Barony of Tirawly, Co. of Mayo, and Province of Con naught .* The Right Rev. Joseph Stock, D. D., Lord Bishop, in 1806 : a R. and V. : The Parish Church is demolished; and the Cathedral, which is in good repair, is used as such: a Glebe House and Plot, in the Town of Killala: there are also some Glebe Lands, the quantify and bounds of Avhich are unknown, situate about a mile from the Cathedral Church : The Rev. Edmund Burton, LL. D., Dean, Rector and Vicar, in 1806: who is non-resident, the Glebe House being in pos session of a tenant, Avho sets up a lease alleged to have been made by a former Dean : the duties are discharged by The Rev. Henry Palmer, A. B., his Curate, at a salary of £75. per annum, and who is resident in the Bishop's Palace. Killala is in the Diocese of Killala, and Province of Tuam. It is 127 m. N.W. from Dublin. The Fairs are holden on the 6th of May, 17th of August, and 8th of November. It has six Post-days in the Aveek. It is situate on a Bay, to which it gives name, on the Atlantic Ocean. Here the French effected a lauding under General Humbert, in 1798 : and of which a most interesting Narrative has been published. The Bishoprick of Killala (valued in the King's Books at ,£23.. 6.. 8 sterling) Avas founded, according to Dr. Beaufort, about the middle of the Fifth century ; ancl in the folloAving century, the See of Achonry was established. They both extend into the Counties of Mayo, and Sligo ; the river Moy and the Ox Mountains forming the boundary between them. The greatest length of Killala is, from East to West, 45 miles, by a breadth of 21 miles. Achonry stretches from North East to South West 28 miles, and is 21 miles broad. The United Sees measure, East ancl West, 55 miles, and, from North to South, 21 miles. The Chapter of Killala is composed ofa Dean, Precentor, and Archdeacon, Avith five Prebendaries. The Crown presents to two parishes, which are the Corps of the respective Deaneries, in each of these Dioceses : the other 48 parishes are in

K I L the gift of the Bishop. The Cathedral of Killala is small, but venerable for its antiquity : it is the only church in the parish, though a Round toAver at the other end of the village indicates the ancient site of another church, of Avhich, however, no vestige remains. The Palace is a very small and ruinous house, ill situated and ill contrived, at the edge of a very fine demesne : But tbe present Bishop is making such additions and improvements as will render it a very com fortable residence. It is not 30 miles distant from the most remote part of either Diocese. In the rebellion of 1798, most of the records in the Registry of the united Dioceses of Killala ancl Achonry Avere destroyed. KILLALOE, in the Barony of Tullagh, Co. of Clare, and Province of Munster : The Right Rev. Lord Robert Tottenham, D. D., Lord Bishop, in 1806: 2

K I L a Rectory entire, Avhich, with the Rectory entire of Donamona, the Rectories of Clonrush, and Moynoe, the Half Rectory of Ogonilloe, and the Vicarage of Fcakle, belong to the Oeconomy of the Cathedral Church of St. Flannan, in the parish of Killaloe: no Church in the other parishes : no Glebe : The Rev. James Martin, A. M., Curate (in 1806), Avho is resident, and is assisted by The Rev. Henry Allen, A. B., Curate, avIio is also resident. Killaloe is in the Diocese of Killaloe, ancl Prov ince of Cashel. It is 86£m. S. W. from Dublin. It has six Post-days in the Aveek ; and is situate upon the river Shannon, over Avhich hereis a Bridge of 19 arches. Here is a considerable Salmon and Eel Fishery. It is a place of great Antiquity. The Diocese of Killaloe (valued in the King's Books at ,£20..0..0 sterling) was founded, according to Dr. Beaufort, early in the Fifth century: in the Twelfth, it Avas incor porated with the ancient Bishoprick of Roscrea, which was founded in 620. Ancl in the year 1752, the See of Kilfenora, Avhich had been established about the TAvclfth century, Avas united to it ; and though very small in extent and A-alue, had con tinued separate till after the Restoration, Avhen it Avas first annexed to the Arch bishoprick of Tuam : That Union continued 81 years, till 1741, when Ardagh being annexed to Tuam, this Bishoprick Avas given in Commendam to the Bishop of Clonfert. The Diocese of Killaloe stretches 80 miles in length, through the Counties of Clare and Tipperary, into the King's County, and includes also a small part of the Queen's County, Gahvay, and Limerick. It varies in breadth from seven to twenty five miles. Kilfenora is confined to the Baronies of Burrin, and Corcomroe, and extends only 18 miles by nine. The Chapter consists of a Dean (see, Kilkeary), Precentor (see Lateragh), Chancellor (see, Toomevara), Trea surer (see, Dromline), and Archdeacon (see, Aghlishcloghane), ancl five Prebend aries. The Church of Killaloe is not large for a Cathedral, but venerable for its antiquity, and in good preservation, though built above 660 years. It serves like many others for the parish church. Very near the little toAvn of Killaloe, in the midst of a fine Demesne, beautifully situate on the Western Bank of the Shannon, stands the Episcopal Residence, a handsome neAV House, erected by the late Arch bishop of Dublin, when Bishop of Killaloe. This See is 50 miles from the South West extremity of the Diocese. — " St. Molualobhair, the grandson of Eocha Bailldearo*, King of North Munster, founded an Abbey here, about the beginning of the Sixth century. He was succeeded by his Disciple St. Flannan, Avho, about the year 639, was consecrated Bishop of the place ; from this time Ave hear no more of it as an abbey. Killaloe was anciently the Resort of many pilgrims." - ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 52. N. W. from Louth.

K I L KILLARAGHT, in the Barony of ■, Co. of Roscommon, and Province of Connaught. According to Mr. Archdall, St. Patrick founded a Nunnery here for the Virgin St. Athracta. D. 470, and her feast, as Patron ess, is celebrated here on the 9th of February, or, more probably, on the llth of August. It is noAv a parish church." ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 635. KILLARD, in the Barony of Ibrickin, Co. of Clare, and Province of Munster : a V., valued in the King's Books at <£'0..10..0 sterling, being one of the parishes Avhich constitute the Union of Inniscathrie. Killard is in the Diocese of Killaloe, and Province of Cashel. It is 7\ m. N. W. from Kilrush. It is situate upon the Atlantic Ocean. It gives title of Baron to the Family of Allington. KILLARDRY, in the Barony of Clanwilliam, Co. of Tipperary, ancl Province of Munster : a Rectory entire, united, at a period prior to any knoAvn Record, to the Chapelry of Clonfinglass, being the Corps of the Prebend thereof, Avhich is valued in the King's Books at £6. S, from Ballymore. — "Here we find three Churches, the first dedicated to St. Aid, Avas Parochial, the next was called Temple Brigid, ancl the third, The Court of St. Brigid. Here were also three Holy Wells, but we knoAV not to Avhom they were dedicated."— ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 716. KILLARGE, in -"the Barony of — , Co. of Carlow, and Province of

Hibern. p. 36. KILLARGY, in the Barony of Dromahaire, Co. of Leitrim, and Province of Connaught: a V. : a Church, in good repair: no Glebe House: 288 acres of Glebe ; a considerable part of which is mountain, and about one mile distant from each other, in different Dioceses : The Rev. According to the Ecclesiastical Report, this Benefice is too small to afford the means of comfort to a Resident Incumbent. Killarney is in a very improving state; not so much owing to the great concourse of visitants whom the beauties osthe Lake attract, as to the judicious attention of the respectable proprietor, Lord Kenmare, and to the encouragement which his Lordship gives to the extension of the Linen Manufacture through that neighbourhood. KILLARVEY, or, KILLARY, in the Barony of Slane, Co. of Meath, and Province of Leinster: a R. and V. : the Rectory is valued in the King's Books at ,£20.. 5. .0 Irish Money: The Rev. George Lambart, the Rector (in 1806), is non-resident, and has not cure of souls: the Vicarage (endowed) is valued in the King's Books at £.3..10..0 Irish Money, being one of the parishes Avhich consti tute the Union of Syddan. John Day, the Incumbent (in 1806), who has cure of souls, and is permitted to reside at Listowell, Avhere he is Curate, and has important duties, to Avhich he assiduously attends : the duties of these parishes are performed by the Curate of Dingle, at a Salary of £20. per annum. k* r l ploughlands and 45 reduced acres, or 285 reduced acres. They are mostly moun tainous, ancl arc situate upon the Atlantic Ocean. KILLROAN, in the Barony of Courceys, Co. of Cork, and Proyipce of Mun ster: a Curacy. It is in the Diocese of Cork, and Province of Cashel. It is 3^ m. S. b. W. from Kinsale. KILLRONAN, in the Barony of Boyle, Co. of Roscommon, and Provinceof Connaught: a V. : a Church, in good repair : no Glebe House, but the Incumbent has memorialed to build one; a Glebe, of 30 acres: The Rev. N. from Carrick on the Shannon. A, .8 Irish Money: a new Church, building: a Glebe House, building; two Glebes; one, of 6 acres, close to the site osthe old church; and the other, of 10 a. 0 r. 2 p., Avithin a fe av perches osthe new church : these Glebes are distant from each other something more than a mile : The Rev. Richard Eyre, the Incumbent (in 1806), avIio has cure of souls, is resident, and discharges the duties in person. This Living is conceived to be of too small value to afford comfort to the Incumbent. Killrossanty is in the Diocese of Lismore, and Province of Cashel. It is 65 m. S. W. b. W. from Kilmacthomas. According to the Ecclesiastical Report, the Rectory and Vicarage ought to be perpetually united. KILLRUSH, in tbe Barony of Balruddery, Co. of Dublin, ancl Province of Leinster : a Chapelry. It is in the Dioceses of Dublin and Glandelagh, ancl Province of Dublin. It is 14^ m. N. b. E. from Dublin. Here are the remains of a noble Castle. It is situate upon the Irish Sea. KILLRUSH, in the Barony of Decies xvithout Drum, Co. of Waterford, and Province of Munster: an entire Rectory, constituting part of the Corps of the Archdeaconry of Lismore : the Chapel, Avhich is in ruins, is valued in the King's Books at ,£4.. 4.. 6. Killrush is in the Diocese of Lismore, and Province of Cashel. It is 2 m. N. W. from Dungarvan. See, Ballybacon, Killgobenet. KILL, ST., v. SHANKILL. . ■■,..,- ..,

KILLSCANNELL, in the Barony of Connello, Co. of Limerick, and Prov ince of Munster : a R. and V., the Vicarage being valued in the King's Books at «£0..13..4 Irish Money , and being one of the parishes Avhich constitute the Corps osthe Chancellorship of Limerick. Killscannell is in the Diocese of Limerick, and Province of Cashel. It is 3f m. S. W. from Rathkeale. See, Rathkeale. KILLSHALVEE, in the Barony of Corran, Co. of Sligo, and Province of Connaught : a V., valued in the King's Books at £!0..2..0 sterling, being one of the parishes svhich constitute the Union of Killaraght. Killshalvee is in the Diocese of Achonry, ancl Province of Tuam. It is 8\ m. W. N. W. from Boyle. See, Killaraght. KILLSHANNY, in the Barony of Corcomroe, Co. of Clare, and Province of Munster: a Rectory Impropriate. It is in the Diocese of Kilfenora, ancl Prov ince of Cashel. It is 2\ m. N. from Innistymon. — " The Cell of Kilshanny, alias' Kilsonna, was annexed to the Abbey of Corcumroe. KILLSHEELAN, in the Barony of Iffa and Offa, Co. of Tipperary, and Province of Munster : a Rectory Impropriate ; and Vicarage, valued in the King's Books at <£l0. sterling, being one of the parishes which constitute the Union of Carrick upon Suir : the Church is in ruins. Killsheelan is in the Diocese of Lismore, ancl Province of Cashel. It is 5 m. W. N.W. from Carrick upon Suir. It is situate near the River Suir. According to the Ecclesiastical Report, the Vicarages of Killsheelan, Killaloan, and Templetenny, ought to be perpetually united, and a church built in the parish of Killaloan, Avhere a glebe ought to be purchased, and a glebe house built. The Crown is the Patron of the Vicarages of Killaloan, and Templetenny. The Earl of Ormond is the Patron of the Vicar age of Killsheelan. See, Carrick upon Suir. KILLSHINANE, in the Barony of Clanmaurice, Co. of Kerry, and Province of Munster : a V., being one osthe parishes Avhich constitute the Union of Bal linacourty. Killshinane is in the Diocese of Ardfert and Aghadoe, and Province of Cashel. Itis 6 m. S. from Listowell. See, Ballinacourty. _. 1

K I L KILLTALLAGH, in the Barony of Trughanacmy, Co. of Kerry, and Province of Munster: a R. and V., Episeopally united to the entire Rectories of Currens, and Killorglin, and the Rectories and Vicarages of Killgarrylander, and Knockane : a Church, in Killtallagh, in good repair : a Glebe House, in Killtallagh, with a Glebe, close to the church, of 6a. Or. 3 p. ; in Killgarrylander, of 1 1 a. 2 r. 14 p., close to the old church; in Currens, of 4 a. 3 r. 16 p., close to the old church ; and there is also a Glebe, said to belong to Knockane, surrounding the old church, of about 1 3 acres ; but it has not been possessed by the six last Incumbents : The Rev. Killtallagh is in the Diocese of Ardfert and Aghadoe, and Province of Cashel. It is 1|- m. N. b. E. from MilltoAvn. The parishes of Knockane, ancl Killorglin, are contiguous (containing, by the same survey, 885 acres), and are separated from the rest of the Union by the River Mang, and by the parish of Killcoleman, Avhich is always included in the Patent with those five parishes, but is, and Avas in 1669, enjoyed by the Crosbie family as an Impropriation. See, Knockane, and Killcoleman. KILLTEAMY, in the Barony of , Co of Limerick, and Province of Munster: aR., being one of the parishes which constitute the Union of the Rectory of Kilmallock. Killteamy is in the Diocese of Limerick, and Province of Cashel. See, Kilmallock. KILLTEEVAGH, in the Barony of Raphoe, Co. of Donegal, and Province of Ulster : a R. and V., being one of the six parishes Avhich constitute the Deanery of Raphoe: a Church. Killteevagh is in the Diocese of Raphoe, and Province of Armagh. The Rectory and Vicarage have been consolidated from time immemo rial, and form but one parish. It is 5 to'. N. W. from Stranorlane. KILLTENNEL, in the Barony of Idrone, Co. of Carlow, and Province of Leinster : a V., valued in the King's Books at «£0..13..4 Irish Money, being one of the parishes Avhich constitute the Union of Lorum. KILLTHOMAS, in the Barony of Loughrea, Co. of Galway, and Province of Connaught: a R. and V., united by the Privy Council, on the llth of March, 1726, and valued in the King's Books at £7.. 3. 4 sterling, being one of the parishes Which constitute the Union of Killinane. Killthomas is in the Dioceses of Clonfert and Kilmacduagh, and Province of Tuam. It is 5 m. N. E. b. N. from Gort. See. Killinane.

K I L KILLTOGHARD, in the Barony of Leitrim, Co. of Leitrim, and Province of Connaught : a R. and V. : two Churches, in good repair; one, in Killtoghard, and one, in Carrick on the Shannon: no Glebe House ; a Glebe, of 200 acres : The Rev. KILLTOOMY, in the Barony of Clanmaurice, Co. of Kerry, aud Provinpe of Munster: a V., being* one of the parishes which constitute the Union of Ballina courty. KILLTORA, in the Barony of Corran, Co. of Sligo, ancl Province of Con naught: a V., being one osthe parishes Avhich constitute the Union of Emlyfadd. KILLTUBRID, in the Barony of Leitrim, Co. of Leitrim, and Province of Connaught : a R. and V. : a Church, in good repair : no Glebe House : The Rev. KILLUCAN, or, KILLUQUIN, in the Barony of Farbill, Co. of West Meath, ancl Province of Leinster: a R. : a Church, lately built, and in complete order: a new Glebe House, on a Glebe of 40 acres, near the church: The Rev. It is noAv a parish church." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 721. KILLUKEN, in the Barony of Boyle, Co. of Roscommon, ancl Province of Connaught: a Prebend and V., valued in the King's Books at £2. sterling, ancl Episeopally united to the Vicarage1, of Creeve, and Tumna, time immemorial : In 1802, the parish of Kilgeffin (Avorth about ,£80. per annum) Avas added to the Union by the present Bishop of Elphin, as it was thought that the Income of the other three (being only about £.150. per annum,) Avas inadequate to the Archdeaconry of Elphin, Avhich these parishes constitute, and which is valued in the King's Books

K I L at o£2..13..0 sterling: a Church, in good repair: no Glebe House: The Rev, Oliver Gary, A. M., the Archdeacon, and Incumbent (in 1806,) >vho has cure of souls, is resident in Elphin, ancl discharges the duties in person. Killuken is in the Diocese of Elphin, and Province of Tuam. It is 2 m. S. S. W. from Carrick on the Shannon. The parishes of Killuken, Creeve, and Tumna, are contiguous, ancl are supposed to extend eleven square miles : The parish of Kilgeffin is about ten miles distant from the others. KILLUKEN, in the Barony of Roscommon, Co. of Roscommon, and Province of Connaught : a V., being one of the parishes which constitute the Union of Kilcooly. Killuken is in the Diocese of Elphin, and Province of Tuam. It is 4 m. S. W. from StrokestoAvn. See, Kilcooly. KILLUMOD, in the Barony of Boyle, Co. of Roscommon, and Province of Connaught : a V., being one of the parishes Avbich constitute the Union of Augh rim. Killumod is in the Diocese of Elphin, ancl Province of Tuam. It is 4 m. S. S. W. from Carrick on the Shannon. See, Aughrim. KILLUNCHE, in the Barony of ■ , Co. of Louth, and Province of Leinster. According to Mr. Archdall, there was a Religious house here ; but Avhich is iioav Avholly unknoAvn. KILLUNKART, in the Barony of Decies within Drum, Co. of Waterford, ancl Provinceof Munster. It is situate upon the River Bricky, a mile ancl an half South from Dungarvan. — " The remains ofa building, said to have been a Com mandery for Knights of St. John of Jerusalem, is still to be seen here." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 689. KILLUR-ANE, in the Barony of Tullagh, Co. of Clare, and Province of Munster : a R. and V. : tbe Rectory constituting part of the Union of Omullud ; the Vicarage, valued in the King's Books at .£'0.. 15.. 0 sterling, being one of the parishes which constitute the Union of Kilseily. KILLURE, in the Barony of Gualtiere, Co. of Waterford, and Province of Munster: a Rectory entire, Avith Kill, St. Laurence, Episeopally uuited, on the 27th of NoA-ember 1787 (Avhen the present Incumbent took possession of the Union), to the Rectories entire of Corbally, and Ross-Duff; and Avith Avhich are holden, by sequestration, the Rectory entire of Kilronan : no Church : no Glebe House: a Glebe, of 10a. 2 r. 1 p., in the parish of Kilronan, contiguous to the site of the old church: The Rev. John Fraser, the Incumbent (in 1806), Avho has cure of souls, is resident in the City of Waterford (Avhere he holds a Curacy), which is Avithin one mile of the commencement of the Union, and performs the duties in person. Killure is in the Diocese of Waterford, and Province of Cashel It is 3 m. S, S. E. from Waterford. The parishes in the Union of Killure are not

<K I L contiguous: that of Kilronan is about throe miles from Killure, and about eight miles from Corbally; and Corbally is distant from Killure about four miles. Kil lure and Kill, St. Laurence, are generally supposed to be one parish. According to the Ecclesiastical Report, the value osthe parishes in this Union is not ,£120. per annum, and cannot be sufficient to afford comfort to the Incumbent. See, Bally gunner. — " A Preceptory was sounded here for the Templars in the 12th century, Avhich Avas afterwards given to the Knights Hospitallers, and became a Commandery." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 689- KILLURIN, in the Barony of Shelmaleire, Co. of Wexford, and Province of Leinster: a V., valued in the King's Books at £7. .6.. 8 Irish Money, and united by Act of Council, in the year 1796 or 1797 (the Act having been destroyed in the Rebellion), to the Impropriate Cores of Chapel Carron, Kilbride, and White church of Glinn : and Episeopally, ever since 1784, to the Impropriate Cure of Ballykeogue: a Church, in repair, iu the parish of Killurin: a Glebe House, newly erected by the present Incumbent, on a Glebe of 20 acres, contiguous to the church : The Rev. Abraham Swanne, the Incumbent (in 1806), Avho has cure of souls, is resident, and discharges the duties in person. Killurin is in the Dio cese of Ferns, ancl Province of Dublin. It is 7 m. S. from Enniscorthy. It is situate on the River Slaney. The Fair is holden on the 21st of August The parishes in the Union of Killurin are all contiguous. KILLURSA, in the Barony of Clare, Co. of Galavay, and Province of Con naught : a R., being one of the parishes winch constitute the Union of Kilkil very. Killursa is in the Diocese of Tuam, ancl Province of Tuam. It is 3\ m. W. from Headford. It is situate on Lough Corrib. There are no traces of this house, but Colgan supposes it to be a parish church near Lough Corrib, Avhich is now called Killursa." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 295. KILLURY, in the Barony of Clanmaurice, Co. of Kerry, and Province of Munster: a R. and V.: a Church, in good repair: no Glebe House: a Glebe, of 3a. 1 r. 30 p., near the church: The Rev. KILLVARNET, in the Barony of Leney, Co. of Sligo, and Province of Con naught: a V., valued in the King's Books at .£4. sterling, and Episeopally united to the V. of Killoran. K I L of Connaught: aR., being one of the parishes whicli constitute the Corps of the Deanery of Kilmacduagh. Killveconty is in the Dioceses of Clonfert and Kilmacduagh, ancl Province of Tuam. It is 2% m. E. b. N. from Gort See, Kilmacduagh. KILLWATERMOY, in tbe Barony of Coshmore and Coshbride, Co. of Waterford, and Province of Munster : an Impropriate Rectory ; and Vicarage, being one of the parishes wliich constitute the Union of Tallow: the Church is in ruins. KillAvatennoy is in the Diocese of Lismore, ancl Province of Cashel- It is 2 m. E. from Tallow. This parish is about two miles in extent from North to South, and two miles and an half from East to West. According to the Eccle siastical Report, the Vicarage of Kilhvatermoy might stand alone: and a Church, and Glebe House, ought to be built in the parish. But should this Vicarage be too small to- afford comfort to the Incumbent, it could be increased by the pur chase of Glebe Lands. See, Talloxv. KILLYBEGGS, in the Barony of Boylagh and Bannogh, Co. of Donegal, and Province of Ulster- a R. ancl V., valued in the King's Books at £.13.. 6.. 0 sterling: a Church : no Glebe House; 2,000 acres of Glebe, for the most part mountainous, but very re-claimable, about three miles from the church : The ReA*. Thomas HaAv kins, the Incumbent (in 1806), avIio having been lately instituted is not resident, but has cure of souls. Killybeggs is in the Diocese of Raphoe, and Province of Armagh. The Rectory and Vicarage have been consolidated from time imme morial, and form but one parish. Itis 124 m. N.W. from Dublin. It isa Sea- Port, with a spacious Harbour, and bas an extensive Herring Fishery. The Fairs are holden on Easter Monday, ancl 12th of November. It has three Post-days in the Aveek.— " A small House was built here, for Friars of the Third Order of St. Francis, by Mac .Sxviny Bannig." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 101. KILLYBEGS, in the Barony of Claine, Co. of Kildare, and Province of Leinster : a V., being one of the parishes Avhich constitute the Union of Clane. , Killybegs is in tbe Diocese of Kildare, ancl Province of Dublin. It is 10 m. W. from Rathcoole. This parish contains 1362 acres of land. See, Clane, and Carooh. — " Tbe Knights Hospitallers had a Commandery here; of which we have no farther account"— ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 321. KILLYGALLY, or, TESSAURAN, in the Barony of Garrycastle, King's County, ancl Province of Leinster: a V., united by Act of Council, on the 21st of February 1804, to the V. ofFirbane: two Churches, lately re-built, and in good order; one in Killygally, the other in Firbane : a. Glebe House, with every neces sary office, has been lately built by the present Incumbent, on one of the glebes of Killyo-ally, about a mile and an half from the church : the two Glebes contain 394 acres : The Rev. Henry Mahon, the Incumbent (in 1806), avIio has cure of souls, is resident, and discharges the duties in person. Killygally is in the Dio cese of Meath, and Province of Armagh. It is 3^ m. N. N. E. from. Banagher. 3 m

K I L ft is situate betAveen the Rivers Shannon, and Brosna. According to Mr. Arch dall, St. Trena, about the end osthe Fifth century, or in the beginning osthe sixth, Avas Abbot here. It is hoav a parish church. KILLYGLEN, or, KILLAGAN, in the Barony of Kilconway, Co. of An trim, and Province of Ulster: aR., united by Charter by James I, in 1609, so the Rectories of Connor and Solar, ancl is one of the parishes Avhich constitute the Prebend of Connor. KILLYMAN, in the Barony of Dungannon, Co. of Tyrone, and Province of Ulster: a R., valued in the King's Books at _£l3. sterling: a Church, in good order : a Glebe House, and a Glebe of 226 English acres contiguous, and near to the church: The Rev. Charles Caulfield, the Incumbent (m 1806), Avho has cure of souls, is resident, and discharges the duties. Killyman is in the Diocese of Arm agh, and Province of Armagh. It is 2 m. N. from Moy. KILLYMARD, in the Barony of Boylagh and Bannogh, Co. of Donegal, and Province of Ulster: a R. and V., being the Corps of the Prebend thereof, which is valued in the King's Books at £6. sterling: a Church*, no Glebe House: a Glebe of good Land, and sufficiently extensive for the complete accommodation of the Incumbent: The Rev. KILLYN, in the Barony of TiraAvly, Co. of Mayo, and Province of Connaught. According to Mr. Archdall, there Avas an Abbey here. KILLYON, in the Barony of Moyfenrath, Co. of Meath, and Province of Leinster: a Curacy, being one of the parishes which constitute the Union of Clonard. KJLMACAHILL, in the Barony of Gowran, Co. of Kilkenny, and Province of Leinster; a V. : a Church; building : no Glebe House, or Glebe: The Rev. 1

K I L William Latta, the Incumbent (in 1806), who has cure of souls, and dischafgeS the duties in person. Kilmacahill is in the Diocese of Leighlin, and Province of Dublin. Itis 2^m. N. from GoAvran. KILMACALLANE, in the Barony of Tiraghrill, Co. of Sligo, and Province of Connaught: a Prebend, ancl Vicarage : tbe Prebend is comprised in a moiety of the tythes of four parishes : The Rev. This abbey is situated to the North West osthe Cathedral (which is now in ruins), on a neck of land between tAvo Loughs, which, according to some authors, evacuate themselves in summer into whirlpools ; however, this rarely happens, as tbe water never goes Off but in a very dry season. The church, though small, is a very neat building. the pillars and arches, from the entrance to the altar part, and those of the East window, are finished in an elegant style, ancl the angles at the East end areAvorked in pillars. To the South of the church is a Sacristy, and adjoining to that a room, Avliere Avas probably deposited the valuable effects belonging to the church, and which being arched, they call the Jail ; on the South of these, is a Chapel and the Refectory ; from the Avhole of this we may infer, that the Canons osthe Monast ery chvelt in separate houses. To the North, about two feet from the church, is an old wall ; an ancient tradition still exists at Kilmacduagh, of its being* once a place of-penance. There is also an Holy Well here, with a circular inclosure. Here is an ancient Round toAver, which leans 17^ feet from its perpendicular.
