KINNITTY, in the Barony of Ballibritt, King's County, and Province of Leinster: a Half Rectory and Vicarage, valued in the King's Books at £2. ster ling, ancl united by Act of Council, on the 14th of December 1796, to the Half Rectory ancl Vicarage of Litterluna, and the Vicarage of Roscomroe : a Church, in good repair, in the parish of Kinnitty : no Glebe House, but the Incumbent is under orders to build : a Glebe, of 21 a. 1 r. lip., in tbe parish of Kinnitty, con venient to the church: The Rev. Abraham DoAvns, A. B., the Incumbent(in 1806), who has cure of souls, and is resident. Kinnitty is in the Diocese of Killaloe, and Province of Cashel. It is 6 m. S. b. W. from Balliboy. The parishes in the Union of Kinnitty are contiguous; their estimated extent, from North to South, being 4 miles, and from East to West, 4 miles. — "An Abbey was founded here in the year 557, Avhen St. Finan, sirnamed Com, of the race of Corcudubne, and a disciple of St. Brendan of Clonfert, who died in 576, Avas Abbot of Cinneteach. The Abbot Colga Mac Conagann died here in 871 : be was esteemed the best ancl most elegant poet then in this kingdom, and Avas also the principal historian." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 401. KINSALE, Avithin the Liberties of the same, Co. of Cork, and Province of Munster: a R. ancl V.: the R. is Impropriate in James Kearney, Esq.: the V.

KIR is valued in the King's Books at <£3. sterling : a Church, in good repair : a Glebe House, in a ruinous state: Glebe Land: The Rev. Samuel Beamish, the Incum bent (in 1806), who has cure of souls : the duties are discharged by his Resident Curate, at a Salary of £.75. per annum. Kinsale is in the Diocese of Cork, and Province of Cashel. It is 136 m. S. W. from Dublin. It is situate on the River Bandon, at the Northern extremity of a commodious and secure Harbour, to Avhich it gives name, on St. George's Channel. The Fairs are holden on the 4th of May, 4th of September, and 21st of November. This town sends one Member to Par liament; Patronage, in the family of Southxvell. The Magistrates are a Sovereign, Recorder, and ToAvn Clerk. It is defended by a strong sort, built by King Charles II, called Charles Fort, on the Eastern entrance of the harbour; the Military establishment of Avhich is under a Governor, Lieutenant Governor, ancl Fort Major. It gives title of Baron to the ancient family of de Courcey, lineally de scended from John de Courcey, Earl of Ulster, who from him have the privilege to be covered in the presence osthe King of England. Here is a Royal Dock-yard. It has six Post-days in the Aveek. The toAvn, Avhich contains at least 10,000 inhab itants, is built on the side of Compas-hill, and close to the water's edge. Accord ing to Mr. Archdall, St. Gobban was Patron of the Monastery of Kingsale. We have no information about the foundation of the house of White Friais : part of the ruins of which still remain in the North end osthe town. K1NSALEBEG, in the Barony of Decies xvithin Drum, Co. of Waterford, and Province of Munster: a Rectory Impropriate ; and Vicarage, being one of the parishes Avhich constitute the Union of Templemihil: the Church is in ruins. Kinsalebeg is in the Diocese of Lismore, ancl Province of Cashel. It is 8|-m. S.W. from Dungai*A*an. It is situate upon tbe River Blackxvatcr, over Avhich it has communication with the town of Youghall by a Ferry-boat. According to tbe Ecclesiastical Report, the Vicarages of Lisgenan ancl Kinsalebeg ought to be per petually united ; and, if a Church, ancl Glebe House, were built in the parish of Kinsalebeg, it is thought, that this would be a good arrangement. See, Templemihil. KINURE, in the Barony of Kinalea and Keiricurrihy, Co. of Cork, ancl Prov ince of Munster: a Rectory Impropriate. It is in tbe Diocese of Cork, ancl Prov ince of Cashel. It is 4 m. S. E. from Kinsale. It is situate upon St. George's Channel. KINVARRA, in the Barony of Kiltartan, Co. of Galway, and Province of Connaught: a V., valued in the King's Books at £.0..13..4 sterling, being one of the parishes which constitute the Union of Kileolgan. Kinvarra is in the Dioceses of Clonfert and Kilmacduagh, and Province of Tuam. It is 7 m. N, W. from Gort. It is situate upon Galway Bay. The Fairs are holden on the 18th of May, and 17th of October. Sec, Kileolgan. KIRCUBBIN, in the Barony of Ardes, Co. of Down, and Province of Ulster.

K N O It is 97 m. N. b. E. from Dublin. The Fairs are holden on the 28th of April, May, August, and November. It has three Post-days in the week. It is situate on Strangford Lough. See, St. Andrew's. KIRKEEL, v. KILKEEL. KISH, v. KESH. KISHCARIGAN, in the Barony of Leitrim, Co. of Leitrim, and Province of Connaught. It is 7 ni. N. E. from Carrick on the Shannon. A village. KNAVENSTOWN, in the Barony of Ophaly, Co. of Kildare, and Province of Leinster: a R. and V. ; the Rectory being appropriated to the Cathedral Church of St. Bridget, in Kildare, and is valued in the King's Books at £2.. 16.. 8 Irish Money ; the Vicarage being the Corps of the Treasurership of the Cathedral : no Church .* no Glebe House, or Glebe Land: The Rev. John Bayly, the Vicar and Treasurer (in 1806), who has cure of souls, and is resident in Dublin, being a Vicar Choral of Christ Church in that City: the duties are performed by The Rev. Henry Bayly, Avithout Salary, the Iucome being very small. Knavenstown is in the Diocese of Kildare, and Province of Dublin. It is 2j m. N. W. from Kildare. According to the Ecclesiastical Report, this Benefice is too small to afford the means of comfort to a Resident Incumbent. KNIGH, in the Barony of Lo w er Ormond, Co. of Tipperary, and Province of Munster : a R. ancl V., the Vicarage being valued in the King's Books at £l. sterling, and being one of the parishes Avhich constitute the Union of Nenagh. Knigh is in the Diocese of Killaloe, ancl Province of Cashel. It is 2fm. N from Nena°*h. See, Nenagh. KNOCK, v. KNOCKDRUMCALRY. KNOCK, in the Barony of Castlereagh, Co. of Doavn, ancl Province of Ulster: a R., united, time immemorial, to the R. of Breda : a Church, in good repair : no Glebe House, but the Incumbent has promised to build one; a Glebe, of 12 acres, a quarter of a mile from the church : The Rev. Mervyn Pratt, the Incumbent (in 1806), who has cure of souls, is resident, and discharges the duties. Knock is in the Diocese of Down, and Province of Armagh. Itis 2f m. S. S. E. from Bel fast. It is situate on the River Lagan. The parishes of Knock, ancl Breda, are contiguous, and contain together 4800 acres of land. The church here is remark ably neat and elegant : It was erected under the direction of Mr. Castell, at the sole expense of Viscountess Dowager Middleton. KNOCKANE, in the Barony of Dunkerron, Co. of Kerry, and Province of Munster : a R. and V., being one of the parishes Avhich constitute the Union of Killtallagh : In 1669, Knockane Avas separated from the rest osthe Union, Avhich Avere then holden together : It Avas united to them, by the Institution of the In cumbent of Knockane, to the other four parishes, in July 1682 ; since which time, they have been holden together. Knockane is in the Dioceses of Ardfert and

K N O Aghadoe,'and Province of Cashel. It is 6^ m. S. S.W. from Milltown. See, Killtallagh: KNOCKANURE, in the Barony of Iraghticonnor, Co. of Kerry, ancl Prov ince of Munster: a V., being one of the parishes AA'hich constitute the Union of Aghavallin. Knockanure is in the Diocese of Ardfert and Aghadoe, and Prov ince of Cashel. It is 4|m. E. b. N. from ListOAvell. See, Aghavallin. KNOCKAVILLY, in the Barony of Muskerry, Co. of Cork, ancl Province of Munster: a Rectory, and Vicarage, valued in the King's Books at <£6..10..0 ster ling, being one of the parishes which constitute the Union of Brinny : a Glebe, of 30 acres, within a quarter of a mile from the ruins of the church ; and 12 acres, about half a mile therefrom, and a mile from the church at Brinny. Knockavilly is in the Diocese of Cork, and Province of Cashel. It is 5 m. N. N. E. from Bandonbridge. See, Brinny. KNOCKBRIDE, in the Barony of Clonchee, Co. of Cavan., and Province of Ulster: a R. ancl V., valued in the King's Books at ,£2..1..4 sterling: a Church, in good repair: no Glebe House; but the Incumbent has memorialed to build; 188 acres of Glebe, contiguous to the church : The Rev. Daniel Palmer, the In cumbent (in 1806), who has cure of souls ; the duties are discharged by a non resident Curate, at a Salary of £75. per annum. Knockbride is in the Diocese of Kilmore, and Pro\dnce of Armagh. It is 5 m. N. from Bailieborough. KNOCKCOMMON, in the Barony of Duleek, Co. of Meath, and Province of Leinster: a R., being one of tbe parishes Avhich constitute the Union of Duleek. Knockcommon is in the Diocese of Meath, and Province of Armagh. It is 3 m. S. from Slane. See,' Duleek. KNOCKDRUMCALRY, in the Barony of Costello, Co. of Mayo, ancl Prov ince of Connaught : a V., being one of the parishes Avhich constitute the Union of Kiltullagh. Knockdrumcalry is in the Diocese of Tuam, and Province of Tuam. It is 6 m. W. b. N. from Ballyhaunis. See, Kiltullagh. KNOCKGRAFFON, in the Barony of Middle Third, Co. of Tipperary, and Province of Munster: a Rectory entire, valued in the King's Books at £.10. Irish Money, and Episeopally united, in 1803, to the Rectory entire of Doggstown : a Church, in good repair, in Knockgraffon : a Glebe House: a Glebe, of 40 acres, at Knockgraffon: The Rev. John Lloyd, the Incum bent (in 1806), who has cure of souls, and is resident. Knockgraffon is in the Diocese of Cashel, and Province of Cashel. It is 4^m. S. from Cashel. The parishes in the Union of Knockgraffon are contiguous; that of Knockgraffon con- taining 4780 acres. According to the Ecclesiastical Report, the small parish of Doggstown would not, if separated from Knockgraffon, afford comfort to a Resid- ent Incumbent. KNOCKMARK, in the Barony of Deece, Co. of Meath, and Pxovince of

K N O Leinster: a R., valued in the King's Books at £4..17..0 Irish Money, being one of the parishes which constitute the Union of Taragh. Knockmark is in the Dio cese of Meath, and Province of Armagh. It is 2f m. W. b. N. from Dunshaglin. This parish contains 1673 acres of land. See, Taragh. KNOCKMORE, in the Barony of Tiraghrill, Co. of Sligo, and Province of Connaught. — '* A Friary Avas erected here, in the 14th century, by O'Gara, and according to some writers,' for Dominican Friars. But the tradition of the place informs us, that it belonged to the Carmelite Friars, and the ruins of O'Conor's Castle still remaining in this village, seems to infer that he Avas the founder." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 637. KNOCKMOURN, in the Barony of Kilnatalloon, Co. of Cork, and Province of Munster : a V., valued in the King's Books at £\..\0..O sterling, and united by Act of Council, many years ago, to the V. of Ballynoe : a Church, repairing, at Knockmourn : no Glebe House: a Glebe, of 3 acres*- close to the church: The Rev. Thomas Campion, the Incumbent (in 1806), avIio has cure of souls, and dis charges the duties in person. Knockmourn is in the Diocese of Cloyne, and Prov ince of Cashel. It is 6m. N. W. from TalloAv. It is situate on the River Bride. The parishes in the Union of Knockmourn are contiguous; their extent being 7 miles from North to South, by 3 miles from East to West. According to the Ecclesiastical Report, each of these parishes, separately, is too small to afford the means of comfort to a Resident Incumbent. KNOCKMOY, in the Barony of Tiaquin, Co. of Galavay, and Provinceof Connaught : a R., being one of the parishes which constitute the Union of Kill ereran. Knockmoy is in the Diocese of Tuam, and Province of Tuam. It is 7 m. S. E. from Tuam. See, Killereran. — " An Abbey, under the Invocation of the Virgin Mary, Avas founded here for Cistertians in the year 1 1 89, or 1 190, by Cathol O'Conor, surnamed Crove-derge, or Red Hand, king of Connaught. This House was a daughter of the Abbey of Boyle." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 266. KNOCKMUILAN, or, KNOCKMYLAND, in tbe Barony of Knocktopher, Co. of Kilkenny, and Province of Leinster. It is 7f m. S. b. W. from Tho mastOAvn. A village. The Fair is holden on the 5th of August. KNOCKNACRIOTH, in the Barony of Kilkea and Moone, Co. of Kildare, and Province of Leinster. It is contiguous to the Nunnery of Graney.— " Here was a Religious House, and some marks of its ruins still remain." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 332. KNOCKNEGAUL, in the County of the City of Limerick, and Province of Munster : a R. and V. ; the Rectory constituting part of the Corps of the Precen torship of Limerick ; and the Vicarage being part of the Corps of the Prebend of Killpeacon. Knocknegaul is in the Diocese of Limerick, and Province of Cashel. It is 4 m. S. b. W. from Limerick. See, Nantinan, and Killpeacon. *.- 3 R

K N O KNOCKTEMPLE, in the Barony of Duhallow, Co. of Cork, and Province of Munster : a R., united for ever, by Act of Council, to the Perpetual Curacy of Kilbolane: a Church, in repair, at Kilbolane : no Glebe, or Glebe House: The Rev. Thomas King, the Incumbent (in 1806), who has cure of souls, is resident, and discharges the duties in person. The Curacy of Kilbolane is £6.. 13.. 4 per annum, which is paid by the Impropriator. Knocktemple is in the Diocese of Cloyne, and Provinceof Cashel. Itis 10 m. S.W. from Charleville. According to the Ecclesiastical Report, neither of these preferments Avill maintain a Clergy man by themselves. KNOCKTOPHER, in the Barony of Knocktopher, Co. of Kilkenny, and Province of Leinster: a R. and V.; the Vicarage being valued in the King's Books at <£8. Irish Money; and united by Act of Council, at a remote period, to the Rectories and Vicarages of Aghavillyr, Dernahensy, Donomagan, Kilkeasy, Kilkeril, Kilmogany, Kilneddy, and Kiltorkin : two Churches ; one, in the parish of Knocktopher, and the other, in the parish of Kilmogany, both in good repair : a Glebe House, in the parish of Knocktopher: there are 40 a. 3 r. 17 p., of Glebe Land, in the parish of Knocktopher, about 16 acres of which adjoin the Glebe House, 15 acres are a mile from it, 5 acres are occupied by the Curate at Kilmo gany: and three small patches about the toAvn of Knocktopher: The Rev. Hans Hamilton, A. M., the Rector and Vicar (in 1806), Avhohas cure of souls in all parts of his Benefice, is resident, and discharges the duties, assisted by his Resident Curate, at a Salary of £90. per annum. Knocktopher is in the Diocese of Ossory, and Province of Dublin. It is 63 m. S. W. from Dublin. It has three Post days in the Aveek. The parishes in the Union of Knocktopher are contiguous. — "A. D. 1356, James, the second Earl of Ormond, founded a Friary here for Car melites, or White Friars, under tbe Invocation of the Virgin Mary." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 375. KNOCKVICAR, or, THE HILL OF VICTORY, in the Barony of Boyle, Co. of Roscommon, and Province of Connaught. It is 4 m. E. from Boyle. — ■' A Monastery for Friars osthe Order of St. Dominick Avas founded on the sum mit of this hill, of which there are now no remains : the foundation has been given to the family of Bingham, but the time of their arrival in Ireland, evidently proves the mistake. A lease of this Abbey was granted to Richard Kendlemarch." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 614. KNOUGH, in the Barony of Morgallion, Co. of Meath, and Province of Leinster ; a V., being one of the parishes Avhich constitute the Union of Drakes tOAvn. Knough is in the Diocese of Meath, and Province of Armagh. It is 4 m. S. S. E. from Nobber. This parish contains 450 acres of land. See, Drakestown. — " Donchad Hua Kervail, Prince of this country, and Edan Coellaidhe, Bishop of Clogher, founded a Priory here for Regular Canons, under the Rule of St. Au- i

LAC gustin, in the year 1 148, Avhich he dedicated to the Saints Peter and Paul."— ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 466. KYLE, or, CLONFERT MULLOE, in the Barony of Upper Ossory, Queen's County, and Province of Leinster: a R. and V., valued in the King's Books at £!0..13..4 sterling, being one of the parishes Avhich constitute the Union of Roscrea : The Church is in ruins. Kyle is in the Diocese of Killaloe, and Prov ince of Cashel. It is if m. N. W. from Burros in Ossory. See, Roscrea. — " This Monastery was founded in the Sixth century by St. Molua, or St. Luan, the son of Carthar of Munster, Avho was educated at Benchor, and died A. D. 622, after having laboured under a severe leprosy for the preceding twenty years. His Festival is observed on the 4th of August. It is now a parish church." — Arch daWs Monast. Hibern. p. 37$. KYLE, in the Barony of Ballagheen, Co. of Wexford, and Province of Leinster. It is 6 m. E. b. N. from Enniscorthy. A village, situate on the River Awin Banna. KYNNETHIN, in the Barony of , Co. of Limerick, and Province of Munster. — " In Michaelmas term, 1300, a writ issued to the Sheriff to distrain the Abbot of Kynnethin, at the suit of Robert de Bland, for the sum of thirteen marcs, an arrear due of the annual rent of 40s. We find no other mention of this Abbey." — ArchdaWs Mo?iast. Hibern. p. 426. L. LACKAGH, in the Barony of Clare, Co. of Galway, and Province of Con- naught : a V., valued in the King's Books at £l..6..8 sterling, being one of tbe parishes which constitute the Union of Killoscobe. Lackagh is in the Diocese of Tuam, and Province of Tuam. It is 10 m. N. E. b. N. from Galway. The Prebend of Lackagh is A-alued in the King's Books at £6. sterling. See, Killoscobe. LACKAGH, in the Barony of Ophaly, Co. of Kildare, and Province of Lein ster: a R. and V., the Vicarage being valued in the King's Books at £2. Irish Money; and Episeopally united to tbe Rectories of Kildangan, and WalterstOAvn, and the Vicarage of Doneny : a Church, in Kildangan, in good repair : no Glebe House: a Glebe, of 18 a. 2 r. l6p., in five lots; four of Avhich, containing 15 a. 3r. 16 p., are near the ruins osthe old church in Lackagh, and four miles and an half from Kildangan Church ; the fifth, containing 2 a. 3 r. 0 p., is in the

LAC parish of Doneny, a mile and an half from the church of Kildangan : The Rev. Arthur John Preston, the Incumbent (in 1806), who has cure of souls in each parish, is resident ih the adjoining parish of Rathangan, and performs the duties in person. Lackagh is in the Diocese of Kildare, and Province of Dublin. It is 2f in. W. from Kildare, It gives title of Baron to the family of Fielding, now Earl of Desmond. The parishes in the Union of Lackagh are contiguous to each other, and contain in all 4464 acres of land. According to the Ecclesiastical Report, Lackagh might be united Avith the Rectory and Vicarage of Doneny. Kijdan gan and WalterstoAvn should be united Avith Nurney. There is a church at Kil dangan, and a House, and Glebe, should be procured for the Incumbent. LACKAN, in the Barony of TiraAvly, Co. of Mayo, and Province of Con naught : a V., valued in the King's Books at £0,.13..4 sterling, and Episeopally united to the Vicarages of Dunfeeny, Killbreedy, Killcummin, ancl Templemurry : a Church, in the parish of Lackan, in bad repair: and a Chapel of Ease, in the parish of Dunfeeny, in good repair : A sum of money has been assessed on the Union, to repair the church at Lackan : a Glebe House, in the parish of Lackan, and 28 acres of Glebe Land contiguous: Tbere are also, in the parish of Killbreedy, three roods of Glebe; and, in that of Dunfeeny, 19^ acres contiguous to the Chapel of Ease: The Rev. James Little, A. M., the Incumbent (in 1806), Avho has cure of souls, is resident, and discharges the duties. The parishes in the Union of Lackan are contiguous ; their estimated extent being 1 1 miles in length, and 5 miles in breadth. It is situate upon the Sea-coast Lackan is in the Diocese of Killala, and Province of Tuam. It is 4_\ m. N. W. from Killala. LACKEEN, in the Barony of Orrery and Kilmore, Co. of Cork, and Province of Munster: a Prebend, valued in the King's Books at £0.. 10.. 0 sterling, being holden Avith the R. and V. of Kilcoleman, and which is for ever united to a small portion of Aghubollogue, under the name of the parish of Magourney : a Church, in repair, at Magourney : a Glebe House, at Magourney ; and a Glebe, of 69 acres, near the church: The Rev. William Butler, the Incumbent (in 1810), avIio has cure of souls, and is resident at Cloyne, being the Bishop's domestic Chaplain. Lackeen is in the Diocese of Cloyne, and Province of Cashel. It is 7 to. S. S. W. from Charleville. The extent of the Union of Lackeen is four miles North and South, by three miles East and West. According to the Ecclesiastical Report, the Benefice of Lackeen is too small to afford the means of comfort to a Resident Incumbent. - LACKIN, v. LECKEN. LACKOWRAN, in the Barony of Decies xvithout Drum, Co. of Waterford, and Provinceof Munster: a Rectory Impropriate; and Vicarage, being one of the parishes whicli constitute the Union of White Church. LackoAvran is in the Diocese of Lismore, and Province of Cashel. According to Dr. Smith, LackoAV ran is a particle of Modeligo. See, White Church.

LAN LADY'S ISLAND, v. MARY'S, ST., ISLAND. LADYTOWN, in the Barony of Great Connel, Co. of Kildare, and Province of Leinster: a R., or Perpetual Curacy, being one of the parishes Avhich con stitute the Union of Great Connel. LadytoAvn is in the Diocese of Kildare, and ProA-ince of Dublin. It is 2\ ra. S. W. from Naas. This parish contains 560 acres of land. According to the Ecclesiastical Report, this Benefice is too small to afford the means of comfort to a Resident Incumbent. See, Great Connel. LAGHY, in the Barony of Tyrhugh, Co. of Donegal, and Province of Ulster. It is 2h m. S. from Donegal. A village. LAMBAY, ISLAND, off the Barony of Balruddery, Co. of Dublin, and Prov ince of Leinster. It is situate in the Irish Sea, 2 miles East from the Main-land. This Island is about 3 miles in length, and \\ mile in breadth, ancl is nearly of an oval form. Here is a very curious ancient fortification. It is remarkable for vast quantities of Rabbits, and Sea-fowl ; and has a curious Well, and fine Spring of Avater, dedicated to the Holy Trinity. Crabs, lobsters, ancl oysters, are taken in great plenty here, and abundance of Kelp is also made on it. In the reign of Queen Elizabeth, a grant osthe Island of Lambay Avas made to Sir William Usher and his heirs for ever, on condition of his paying £6. per annum to the See of Dublin. It is mentioned by Ptolomey, and is called by Pliny, Limnus, which is thought by Mr. Beaufort to be a corruption from the ancient British, Lan-n'-iii, or, Intirely in the Water. LAMBEG, in the Barony of Belfast, Co. of Antrim, and Province of Ulster: a R., valued in the King's Books at «£l.. 10.. 0 sterling: a Church, in good repair: no Glebe, or Glebe House : Tbe Bishop is Rector; has cure of souls; the duties are discharged by a Resident Curate, at a Salary of ,£68. per annum, being the Avhole Income of the parish. Lambeg is in the Diocese of Connor, and Province of Armagh. It is 2_j m. N. E. from Lisburn. Itis situate upon the River Lagon. — " Mac Donnell built a small Monastery here, in the 15th century, for Francis can Friars of the third Order." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 9 LANESBOROUGH, in the Barony of Rathline, Co. of Longford, ancl Prov ince of Leinster; in the parish of Rathline. It is 62^ m. W. N. W. from Dublin. The Fair is holden on the 12th of February. It gives title of Earl to the family of Butler. It is situate upon the River Shannon, over Avhich here is a bridge, into the County of Roscommon. LANGFIELD, LOWER, in the Barony of Omagh, Co. of Tyrone, and Prov ince of Ulster : a R. and V.; a. Church, old, but in repair: a Glebe House; one Glebe of 90 acres, on Avhich the Glebe House stands, near the church; and a mountain Glebe of 1520 acres, two miles from the other Glebe: The Hon. and Rev. Edmund Knox, the Incumbent (in 1806), who has cure of souls, but being bene ficed in the Diocese of Armagh, he does duty there; the duties here are discharged

L A T by a Curate, resident in the Glebe House, at a Salary of £ 100. per annum, and 3fr acres of land. Lower Langfield is in the Diocese of Derry, and Province of Armagh. LANGFIELD, UPPER, in the Barony of Omagh, Co. of Tyrone, and Prov ince of Ulster: a R. and V., valued in the King's Books at ,£10. sterling: a Church, building: a Glebe House; 32 acres of Glebe, near the church: The Rev. Richard Babington, the Incumbent (in 1806), who being Curate of Derry, is alloAved to reside there until his church is built: The duties are performed by a Curate, resident in the Glebe House, at a Salary of £75. per annum. Upper Langfield is in the Diocese of Derry, and Province of Armagh. It is 8§- m. W. b. N. from Omagh. LARACOR, or, LEICOR, in the Barony of Moyfenrath, Co. of Meath, and Province of Leinster: a V., valued in the King's Books at £6.,0..9 Irish Money: a Church, in good repair : no Glebe House : one acre of Glebe, close to the church, and 20 acres, at half a mile distance : The Rev. Joseph Sandys, the In- cumbent (in 1806), Avho has cure of souls, and lives on his parish in the Diocese of Down ; the duties are discharged by his Resident Curate, at a Salary of £!75. per annum. Laracor is in the Diocese of Meath, and Province of Armagh. It is if m. S. from Trim. A glebe house is greatly wanted in this parish. LARAH, in the Barony of Tullaghgarvy, Co. of Cavan, and Province of Ul ster: a V., with the V. of Drung. Larah is in the Diocese of Kilmore, and Prov ince of Armagh. It is 5^ ____. S. E. from Cavan. The Right Rev. and Hon. Percy Jocelyn, D.D., Lord Bishop, in 1810. lt is 2\ m. W. b. N. from Leighlin- Bridge. It is situate near the RiA*er Barrow. It Avas incorporated in the year 1216, and the extent of its liberties Avere marked by large stones, inscribed, " Ter minus Burgens. Lechlinen. hie lapis est." One of these stones stands near Leighlin- Bridge, another near Wells, and a third in the Mountains. It Avas formerly a City. The Bishoprick of Leighlin, according to Dr. Beaufort (which is valued in the King's Books at £50. Irish Money), Avas established in 632 : it was united to the Bishoprick of Ferns in the year 1600. It comprehends the entire County of Carlow, a considerable part of the Queen's County, and extends into the Counties of WickloAV, and Kilkenny. This Diocese is of a A*ery irregular form ; being in some places but six, and in none above thirteen miles broad, though it is thirty-nine miles long from North to South. The Chapter of Leighlin is com posed ofa Dean (see, f Veils), Precentor (see, Nurney), Chancellor (see, Killinane) Treasurer, Archdeacon (see, Clonmore), ancl four Prebendaries. The Cathedral, though not large, is very neat, and serves for the parish church. — " St. Gobban founded a celebrated Abbey here.— St. Stephen's Priory, Avas founded, or more probably endoAved, by Burchard. a Norwegian captain ; he Avas the son of Gurmund ; he Avas buried in tbe choir of the Cathedral, under a marble monument, whereon was his effigies, with a Latin inscription commemorative of the above. This Priovy, being situated in a depopulated and wasted country, and the Prior having given refuge and succour to his Majesty's good subjects in this neighbourhood, ancl intending to pursue that laudable practice, tbe King, Edward tbe Second, therefore granted them a concordatum on the 1st of May 1372- We cannot say to Avhat Order this priory did originally belong. It Avas dissolved in the year 1432, by the authority of Pope Eugene IV., and the lands thereunto belonging were annexed to the Deanery of Leighlin, at the request of Nicholas Cloal the Dean." — ArchdaWs Monast. St. Michael's, an entire Rectory, partly within the City, and partly in the County osthe City of Limerick : the Vicarage being valued in the King's Books at <£0..5..0 sterling; and united, at a period prior to any existing Record, to the entire Rectories of Ardagh, Clon crema, and Killdeemo, with its Perpetual Curacy; being the Corps of the Archdeaconry, which is valued in the King's Books atc£l6. Irish Money; a Church, in Killdeemo, in good repair: St Michael's Church has been ordered to be rebuilt, and a Cess has been laid on for that purpose : an Archdeaconry House, in Limer ick ; and a Glebe House, on the Curate's Glebe, at Killdeemo : five Glebes; one, of 0 a. 1 r. 7 p., in St. Michael's, close to the site of the old church : another, of 3._\ acre, belonging to the Archdeacon, in Killdeemo, close to the church : the third, of 6_\ acres, belong ing to the Curate, in Killdeemo, and adjacent to'the Archdeacon's : the fourth, of 1 acre, in Ardagh, close to the site of the old church ; and the fifth, a mile from it, containing 14 a. 2 r. 36 p. : Averell Hill, D. D., the Archdeacon (in 1806), Avho has cure of souls in each parish, is resident, and performs the duties of St. Michael's parish in person, assisted by a Curate : He is also attendant on the Cathedral: The Curate of Killdeemo is resident, and has no Salary, having been endowed by the Archdeacon (who also fre quently attends in person) Avith Glebe and Tythes : the duties of the parish of Ardagh are performed by the Incumbent osthe con tiguous parish of Rathronan, at a Salary of £20. per annum. These United parishes are not contiguous. According to the Ecclesiast ical Report, each of the parishes in this Union, separately, is too small to afford the means of comfort to a Resident Incumbent. St. Munchin's, an entire Rectory, partly Avithin the City, and partly in the County osthe City. of Limerick; the Vicarage being valued in the King's Books at ,£l..6..8 Irish Money; and united, at a period prior to any existing Record, to the Rectories of Drehidtarsny. and Killconygayn, and the Rectory and Vicarage of Killonehon, being the Corps of the Prebend thereof, which is valued in the King's Books at ,£2.. 13. .4 Irish Money : a Church, in the parish of St. Munchin, in good repair : a Glebe House, in St. Munchin's, with a garden near it ; a Glebe, of 5 a. 1 r. 24 p., in three divisions, in Killonehon, close to the site osthe old church : The Rev. John Duddell, A. M-, the Prebendary (in 1806), who has cure of souls

L I M in each parish, is resident, and performs the duties of the parish of St, Munchin in person; the duties of Killonehon are attended by the Curate of the neighbouring parish of Killpeacon, at a Salary of £3. per annum. The parishes in this Union are not con tiguous. St. Nicholas's, a Rectory and Vicarage, partly Avithin the City, and partly in the County of the City of Limerick. See, St. Mary's. Limerick is in the Diocese of Limerick, and Province of Cashel. The Right Rev. Charles Warburton, D. D., Lord Bishop, in 1810. It is 94 m. S. W. from Dublin. It has six Post-days in the Aveek. The Markets are on Wednesday, and Saturday. The Fairs are holden on Easter Tuesday, 4th of July, 4th of August, and 12th of December. There isa Privilege annexed to the Fair, Avhich is holden on the 4th of August, that, during fifteen days, no person can be arrested in the City or Liberties, on any Process issuing out of tbe Tholsel Court of Limerick, This City sends one Member to Parliament, The Magistrates are a Mayor, two Sheriffs, a Recorder, Town Clerk, Aldermen, and Burgesses; it hath also a Mil itary Governor, Constable, and Town Major. It is composed of the Irish and English toAvn ; the latter standing on the King's Island, Avhic.h is formed by the River Shannon, and which admits Ships of 500 tons burden to its Quays. It is the Chief toAvn in the county; and gives title of Viscount to the family of Hamilton _ The population is estimated at upAvards of Forty thousand. The Bishoprick of Limerick (valued in the King's Books at £.40. sterling) was united, according to Dr. Beaufort, in 1663, to those of Ardfert and Aghadoe, Avhich had long been so in corporated, as to form but one Diocese. Ardfert, or, Ardart, vvas established in the Fifth century, ancl Limerick before the Thirteenth. The latter extends in length, from East to West, 27 miles in the County of Limerick, and 17 miles in breadth; taking in a small part of Clare. The Bishoprick of Ardfert, which in cludes the whole county of Kerry, and a portion of Cork, is 52 miles long from North to South, and 48 miles broad. There are 71 miles from one extremity of the Union to the other. The Chapter of Limerick consists of a Dean, Precentor (see, Nantinan), Chancellor (see, Rathkeale), Treasurer (see, St. Patrick's), ancl Archdeacon, and 1 1 Prebendaries. The Cathedral of Limerick is an ancient and venerable pile. The Bishop's Palace is a comfortable modem house, pleasantly situate on the Shannon, at the West end of the City; about 30 miles from the bounds of the Diocese of Limerick, and 80 miles from some parts of Ardfert.— " About the time of the arrival of the English (in 1174), an House Avas founded here for Black Nuns of the Order of St. Augustin, by Donald O'Brien, King of Limerick, avIio dedicated it to St. Peter. — In the reign of King John, a Friary avrs sounded under the Invocation of St. Mary and St. EdAvard the King, by Simon Minor, a citizen of Limerick, for Regular Canons of the Order of St. Augustin.

L T S This Priory, situated near Ball's-Bridge, was granted at the Suppression to Edmund Sexton. — A Dominican Friary Avas founded here under the Invocation of St. Saviour, by Donogh Carbreacb O'Brien, king of Thomond. He was interred here in tbe year 1241, in a tomb Avith his statue placed over it. We are told by another writer, that he A\ras interred at Killaloe. Part of the Friary is now" converted into a tan-yard, and a large barrack has been erected on tbe other part: some small remains of the church, Avails, &c, may yet be seen A Gray Friary Avas founded in the reign of King Henry III, by O'Brien, a lineal descendant of the kings of Limerick and Thomond, This Friary stood without the town Avail, and Avhere the County court-house is now erected. The old church has been since converted into tbe County hospital. Wadding says, that another Franciscan Monastery was founded here in the year 1293, in tbe King's Island near Limerick.— The August inian Friary, generally called The House of the Blessed Virgin Mary, and of The Holy Cross, Avas founded in the 13th century by O'Brien. It is supposed tbat this Friary Avas situated near Quay-lane ; but even a trace of it is not now to be found. — The Knights Templars had an House near to the Augustinian Friary, of which the smallest remains are now not discoverable." — ArchdaWs iMotiast. Hibern. pp. 426. et seq. LINALLY, in the Barony of , Co. of Antrim, and Province of Ulster. — " An ancient Abbey of this name is placed by Conry, expressly in this county." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 9- LINN, in the Barony of Belfast, Co. of Antrim, and Province of Ulster. — " St. Darerca, sister to St. Patrick, was Abbess of a Nunnery in Linn, a spacious plain, near Carrickfergus. It is now unknown." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 9- LINNLEIRE, v. LYNNE. LINTOWN FACTORY, within the County of the City of Kilkenny, and Province of I_einster. It is situate close upon the High-road, on a lofty situation, over the Town of Kilkenny, ancl about three quarters ofa mile from the Market place. This Establishment was founded and endowed by Bishop Pococke, the Antiquary ancl Traveller, who left an estate, which now (in 1808) produces about £700. per annum, for its support. LION, ISLAND, off the Barony of Ballinahinch, Co. of Galavay, and Prov ince of Connaught. LI SANE, v. LISSAN. LISBELLA, in the Barony of Tyreskenedy, Co. of Fermanagh, and Prov ince of Ulster. It is 4\ to. N. W. from Lisnaskea. The Fairs are holden on the llth of May, 20th of June, foth of November, and 23d of December. It is a Chapelry, in the Diocese of Clogher, and Province of Armagh. LISBUNNY, in the Barony of Upper Ormond, Co. of Tipperary, and Prov ince of Munster : a R. and V., being one of the parishes which constitute the 3t

L I S Union of Kilmore. Lisbunny is in the Diocese of Killaloe, and Province of Cashel. It is 1 m. S. E. from Nenagh. See, Kilmore. LISBURN, formerly LISNAGARVY, in the Barony of Massareen, Co. of Antrim, and Province of Ulster : a R. : a good Church : the Cathedrals of Down and Connor being in ruins, this Church was made a Cathedral for both Dioceses by Patent, 17th October 1662 : a Glebe House, in Lisburn, near the church, but no Glebe : S. Cupples, D. D., the Incumbent (in 1806), Avho has cure of souls, is resident, and discharges the duties, assisted by a Resident Curate, at a Salary of «£75. per annum. Lisburn is in the Diocese of Connor, and Province of Armagh. It is 73 m. N. b. E. from Dublin. The Fairs are holden on the 23d of July, and 5th of October. It has six Post-days in the week. This Town sends one Member to Parliament : one half of the Patronage of this Borough is in the Marquis of Hertford. It gives title of Earl to the Family of Vaughan. It is situate on the River Lagan. It possesses particular Privileges for its fidelity, in 1641. It is large and handsome, and is equally noted for the neatness of its buildings, and the urbanity of its inhabitants. LISCARROL, in the Barony of Orrery and Kilmore, Co. of Cork, and Prov ince of Munster: a V., valued in the King's Books at ,£5..10..0 sterling, and holden with the V. of Kilbrin. Liscarrol is in the Diocese of Cloyne, and Prov ince of Cashel. It is 7\ m. S. W. from Charleville. The Fairs are holden on the 1st and 31st of May, 31st of August, and 29th of November. The Castle is in ruins. According to the Ecclesiastical Report, this Benefice is too small to afford the means of comfort to a Resident Incumbent. See, Kilbrin, and Cooliney. LISCARTEN, in the Barony of Navan, Co. of Meath, and Province of Leinster : a R., valued in the King's Books at «£9..6..0 Irish Money, being one of the parishes which constitute the Union of Ardbraccan. Liscarten is in the Diocese of Meath, and Province of Armagh. It is 2\ m. N. W. from Navan. This parish contains 706 acres of land. See, Ardbraccan. The Castle here was the birth place of the first Lord Cadogan, to which family it belongs. LISCLEARY, or, LISLEY CLERRIGGE, in the Barony of Kinalea and Kerricurrihy, Co. of Cork, and Province of Munster: a Prebend, valued in the King's Books at £3. sterling : no Church : no Glebe House, or Glebe : The Rev. William Waller, the Prebendary (in 1 806), Avho has cure of souls : the occasional duties are performed by a Curate, Avho is resident in an adjoining parish, at a Salary of ,£10. Liscleary is in the Diocese of Cork, and Province of Cashel. It is 6 m. S. S. E. from Cork. It is situate upon the River Awinboy. This parish consists of two separate parts, betAveen which other parishes intervene : and, according to the Ecclesiastical Report, each of these parts, separately, is too small to afford the means of comfort to a Resident Incumbent. LISCOLEMAN, in the Barony of Shilelagh, Co. of Wickloav, and Province of 2

L I S Leinster : a V., being one of the parishes Avhich constitute the Union of Aghold, Liscoleman is in the Diocese of Leighlin, and Province of Dublin. It is 3\ vn. N.E. from TuIIoav. See, Aghold. LISCORMUCK, or, AGLISHCORMUCK, in the Barony of Coonagh, Co. of Limerick, and Province of Munster: an entire Rectory, valued in the King's Books at ,£3..1..0 sterling; being one osthe parishes Avhich constitute the Corps of the Precentorship of Emly : the duties of Liscormuck, and Listeely, are per formed by The Rev. G. Wall, Rector of the adjoining parish (in 1806), at a Salary of £5. per annum. Liscormuck is in the Diocese of Emly, and Province of Cashel. It is 6 m. E. b. N. from Six Mile Bridge. This parish contains 1275 acres of land. See, Isert Laurence. LISELTIN, or, LISLAGHTIN, in the Barony of Iraghticonnor, Co. of Kerry, ancl Province of Munster : a V., being one of the parishes which constitute the Union of Aghavallin. Liseltin is in the Diocese of Ardfert and Aghadoe, and Province of Cashel. It is 9 rn. S. W. from Tarbert See, Aghavallin. — " A Monastery Avas founded here, in the year 1464, by O'Connor, Prince of Kerry, for Franciscan Friars of the strict observance. The Steeple, Choir, and many other parts of the building may still be seen." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 304. LISGENAN, in the Barony of Decies xvithin Drum, Co. of Waterford, ancl Province of Munster : a Rectory Impropriate : and Vicarage, constituting part Osthe Union of Templemihil : the Church is in ruins. Lisgenan is in the Diocese of Lismore, arid Province of Cashel. It is 5f to. S. from Dungarvan. Itis situate upon the River Licky, and near to St. George's Channel. See, Templemihil, aud Kinsalebeg. L1SGOOL, in the Barony of Magheraboy, Co. of Fermanagh, and Province of LJlster. — " In the early ages of Christianity, a Monastery Avas founded here, Where Ave find the Festival of St. Aid, or Hugh, of Lisgovel, Avas observed on the 25th of January. An Abbey, under the Invocation of the Virgin Mary, was afterwards founded here, and probably on the site of the ancient Monastery, for Regular Canons, folloAving the rule of St. Augustin, by Mac Noellus Mackenlef ■King of Ulster, in the year 1106. — This abbey having gone to ruin for want of necessary repairs, and Divine Service being totally neglected therein, the Abbot Cahill Mac Brian, Mac Cuchonnaght Maguire, entered into articles Avith Cuchon naght Fitz-Cuehonnaght Maguire, lord osthe Country of Fermanagh, to restore it to its pristine state. Maguire being grieved at seeing the church, which he and the principal people osthe countiy had chosen for the place of their sepulture, so nearly demolished, requested the before mentioned Lord Abbot to surrender his title, and suffer him to provide another Order for the House, who should keep it in proper repair, and engage that there should be constantly Divine Service therein. The Abbot, together with the Bishop and Chapter, entered into an agreement wbich received the Confirmation of the Pope, who ordered the Franciscan Friars to take

L I S possession of the abbey: and the Lord Maguire made a recompence to the Abbot Cahill, of ten dry Cows yearly, to him and his lineal heirs for ever. In this deed, a fine was ordered of — cows to the O'Hosies and Mac Crifferties, the Poets, who were to reprove, infame arid reprehend, in their satirick Avritings, every disturber of the Friars, othenvise the ordinary fine of 20 cows Avas to be levied out of their own proper goods and lands.— Maguire afterwards began to rebuild the Abbey in a most agreeable and eligible situation : but before the completion of the building, the destroying poAvers of King Henry VIII overwhelmed it, in the year I530._ It was granted to Sir John Davis, Knight."— ArchdaWs Jllonast. Hibern. p. 263. LISGOOLD, in the Barony of Barrymore, Co. of Cork, and Province of Munster : a V., united from time immemorial, ancl constituting with the Rectory and Vicarage of Ballintemple, the Rectory of Ballycaraney, the Rectory and Vicarage of Imphrick, and two thirds of the Rectory of Kilcredan, the Corps of the Precentorship of Cloyne, Avhich is valued in the King's Books at £.3. sterling: and Avith Avhich is holden, by Faculty, the Union of Clonmell : a Church, in repair, lately built at Lisgoold: no Glebe House: three Glebes; one, of 7 acres, at Cloyne ; another, of 2 acres, in two separate portions, at Ballintemple, ancl not far from the old church there : the third, of 3 roods, at Ballycaraney and Imphrick; but none of these glebes are contiguous, or near the church of Lisgoold : Francis Atterbury, D. D., the Incumbent (in 1806), who has cure of souls, and is resident on his other Benefice at Clonmell, about 7 miles from Lisgoold : the duties are chiefly performed by his Curate, The Rev. Mr. Pratt, at a Salary of £J60. per annum. Lisgoold is in the Diocese of Cloyne, and Province of Cashel. It is 6f m. S. S. E. from Rathcormuck. The Fairs are holden on the 1st of May, 25 th of June, 1st of November, and 21st of December. The parishes of Lisgoold and Bally caraney are contiguous, their extent being 6 miles from East to West, and 3 miles from North to South. The other parishes of the Union of Lisgoold are in detached parts of the Diocese : Ballintemple being about 5 miles to the South ; Kilcredan about the same distance to the South East ; ancl Imphrick at least 15 miles to the North West from Lisgoold. According* to the Ecclesiastical Report, none of these Livings, taken separately, can afford comfort to an Incumbent, except, perhaps, Ballintemple, Avhich might produces 100. per annum, and yet leave enough to support the Precentorship from the four other parishes : It has also a Glebe, and might have a Church. See, Clonmell. LISKEEVY, in the Barony of Downamore, Co. of Galavay, and Provinceof Connaught: a V., being one osthe parishes which constitute the Union of Tuam. Liskeevy is in the Diocese of Tuam, and Province of Tuam. It is 6f m. N.W. from Tuam. See, Tuam. LISKINFERE, v. LESKINFERE. LISLAGHTIN, v. LISELTIN. LISLEE, in the Barony of Barryroe, Co. of Cork, and Province of Munster : i

L I S a V., valued in the Kings Books at £6. sterling, and Episeopally united, in 1805, to the R. of Kilsillagh : a Church, in Lislee, in good repair : no Glebe House •. an ancient Glebe, of 9 a. 3 r. 22 p., and a new Glebe, granted at a rent by The Right Hon. The Earl of Shannon, adjoining, of 32 a. Or. 18 p.: The Rev. Henry Jones, the Incumbent (in 1806), who has cure of souls, and is preparing to build a Glebe House : the duties are discharged by a Resident Curate. Lislee is in the Diocese of Ross, and Province of Cashel. It is 6 m. S. E. from Clognakilty. It is situate upon St. George's Channel. The parish of Kilsillagh is a very small piece of ground, entirely surrounded by the parish of Lislee ; the estimated extent of which is, including Kilsillagh, 4 miles from North to South, and l£ mile from East to West. The Rectory of Lislee is Impropriate in The Earl of Shannon. According to the Ecclesiastical Report, each of these parishes, separately, is too small to afford the means of comfort to a Resident Incumbent. L1SMAKEERY, or, LISMACDIRY, in the Barony of Connello, Co. of Limer ick, and Province of Munster : an entire Rectory, valued in the King's Books at £\. Irish Money, being one osthe parishes Avhich constitute the Union of Askeaton. Lismakeery is in the Diocese of Limerick, and Province of Cashel. It is 5 m, N. W. from Rathkeale. See, Askeaton. LISMAL1N, in the Barony of SleAvardagh and Compsey, Co. of Tipperary, and Province of Munster : a R. and V., united by Act of Council, in 1801, to the Vicarage of Ballingarry, and the Rectories and Vicarages of Modeshill, and Mowney : a Church, in good repair, at Lismalin : no Glebe House . a Glebe, of 33 acres, at Modeshill : The Rev. James G. Fitzgerald, the Incumbent (in 1806), who has cure of souls, is resident in the adjoining parish, and performs the duties, assisted by a Curate. Lismalin is in the Diocese of Cashel, and Province of Cashel. It is 4^ m. S. W. from Callan. Here are the ruins ofa Castle. The parishes in the Union of Lismalin are contiguous ; that of Lismalin containing 2660 acres. According to the Ecclesiastical Report, the parish of Ballingarry should be separated ; and the other three parishes should be holden together. See, Ballin- garry. LISMORE, in the Barony of Coshmore and Coshbride, Co. of Waterford, and Province of Munster : a R. and V. : the Rectory has been united time out of mind, and probably at the first establishment of tlie Cathedral, to the Rectory of Macollop: these Rectorial Tythes belong to the Oeconomy of the Cathedral of Lismore, and are appropriate for keeping the Cathedral in repair : the Vicarage has also been united, time out of mind, to the Vicarage of Macollop: these Vicar ial Tythes, valued in the King's Books at £20. sterling, belong to the five Vicars Choral of Lismore : who are alleged to have the cure of souls, and they do not dispute it ; but, for the Avant of the Charter, this, as well as many other things concerning the Establishment of this Cathedral, cannot be ascertained : The Cathedral, at Lismore, is the only Church ia the Union, (Avhich frorii its ex-

L I S tent requires at least tAvo churches) ; And being in indifferent repair, is about to undergo a thorough renovation : no Glebe House, or Glebe: the duties are per formed by one of the Vicars Choral, Avho ahvays resides in Lismore, at a Salary of ,£50. per annum. The parishes in the Union of Lismore are contiguous, and are very large. Lismore is in the Diocese of Lismore, and Province of Cashel. The Dean of Lismore has a Peculiar jurisdiction over the three parishes of Lismore, TalloAV, and Macollop. It is 101 ni. S. W. b. S. from Dublin. The Fairs are holden on the 25th of May, and September, and 12th of November. It has six Post-days in the week. Here is a Free School. The Castle Avas built by King John, on the ruins of the Abbey of St. Carthagh: It belonged to the Duke of Devonshire, and gave birth to the great philosopher, Robert Boyle : It is boldly seated on the verge of a rocky hill, which rises almost perpendicularly, to a con siderable height, OArer the River Blackwater. It was for many years an Episcopal residence, until Myler Magrath, Archbishop of Cashel, and Bishop of this See, granted the Manor of Lismore to that celebrated scholar and soldier, Sir Walter Raleigh, in the reign of Queen Elizabeth, at the yearly rent of <£l3..6..8 : But this estate being lopped off Avith his head, in the reign of King James tbe First it afterwards came into the hands of Sir Richard Boyle, avIio purchased all Sir Walter's lands. Here is a fine bridge over the River Blackwater, whicli was erected at a very great expense by the Duke of Devonshire ; and which is re markable for the extent of its principal arch, the span of it being 90 feet. Below the toAvn is a rich fishery for salmon, Avhich is the greatest branch of trade here. The public road to Cork Avas formerly through this toAvn. The Bishoprick of Lismore, according to Dr. Beaufort, was founded in the beginning of the Seventh century. It wras united to the See of Waterford, in the year 1536. The Chapter of Lismore consists of a Dean (see, Tubrid), Precentor (see, Ardmore), Chancellor (see, Derrygrath), Treasurer (see, Newcastle), and Archdeacon (see, Ballybacon), and ten Prebendaries. The Cathedral is spacious, and handsome. There are some parts of the Diocese of Lismore 35 miles distant from the city of Waterford. See, Waterford. — " Some writers affirm, that there was neither Church nor City here before the time of St. Mochuda ; yet Ave find, that John Ayas Bishop of Lis more in the time of St. Senan, who lived about the year 540. — An Hospital for Lepers was founded here under the Invocation of St. Brigid, to Avhich several lands did belong, as appears from a Registry compiled some time after. 1467, Avhen the Master of the Hospital, styled Prior of Lismore, was in his 120th year:. At the time of the general suppression, these lands were unknoAvn. — A Cell for an Anachorite, belonged to the church of Lismore, Avhich Avas endowed Avith the lands of Baliyhaufy or Anchoret's toAvn, a burgage in Lismore, six stangs of land, a field called Gottrimenyearty, and two small gardens, the whole of the annual value of ,£10." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. pp. 691. et seq. LISMULLEN, in the Barony of Skryne, Co. of Meath, and Province of

L I S Leinster: a Chapelry, being one of the parishes which constitute the Union of Skryne. Lismullen is in the Diocese of Meath, and Province of Armagh. It is 5 m. S. S. E. from Navan. This parish, with the parish of Templecaman, contains 650 acres of land. See, Skryne. Here is a Seat of Lord Dillon. According to Mr. Archdall, Alicia, sister to Richard de la Corner, Bishop of Meath, founded a Religious House in this village in the year 1240, under the Invocation of the Holy Trinity, for Nuns following the Rule of St. Augustine. LISNADILL, in the Barony of Fews, Co. of Armagh, and Province of Ulster: a Perpetual Curacy: a Church, in good order: an elegant Glebe House, on a Glebe of 63 English acres, lying together, and near the church : The Rev. J. Paul, the Incumbent, in 1 806. Lisnadill is in the Diocese of Armagh, and Province of Armagh. It is 2f m. S. from Armagh. The elegant church, and glebe house here, were erected by Primate Rokeby. LISNAKILL, or, LISTINE, in the Barony of Middle Third, Co. of Water ford, and Province of Munster: a Rectory entire, constituting, with part osthe Rectory of Kilmeaden, the Corps osthe Treasurership of Waterford, which were probably united at the same time when the Deanery was established, and Avhich is valued in the King's Books at £10. Irish Money : no Church: a Glebe House, in Trinity parish, in theCity of Waterford, belonging to the Treasurer: a Glebe, of 5 a. 1 r. 32 p., at Lisnakill, very near the site of the old church: The Rev. William Bushe, the Incumbent (in 1806), Avho has cure of souls, and resides in the Diocese of Dublin, where he has another Benefice, Avith cure of souls: his Reading and Preaching turns in the Cathedral are performed by a Substitute, at a Salary of £30. per annum; and the occasional duties of Lisnakill are performed by the Curate of the next parish, at a Salary of £6, per annum. Lisnakill is in the Diocese of Waterford, and Province of Cashel. It is 4 m. W. b. S. from Waterford. This parish contains about 900 acres of land. LISNARICK, in the Barony of Lurge, Co. of Fermanagh, and Province of Ulster. It is 3 J m. S. from Kesh. The Fairs are holden on the 12th of January, 5th of April, 9th of May, 22d of June, and 15th of October. LISNASKEA, or, LISNESKEA, in the Barony of Magherastephana, Co. of Fermanagh, and Province of Ulster: a Chapelry. It is 70 m. N. E. from Dub lin. The Fairs are holden on Monday before Easter Sunday, Monday after Ascension, and 10th of October. It has six Post-days in the week. It is in the Diocese of Clogher, and Province of Armagh. LISNAVILLA, v. TEMPLENOE. LISNINNY, in the Barony of Moycashel, Co. of West Meath, and Prov ince of Leinster. It is 2\ m. S. W. from Killbeggan. A village. LISPOLE, in the Barony of Corcaguinny, Co. of Kerry, and Province of Munster ; in the parish of Kinnard. It is 2s- va. S. E. from Dingle. LISRONAGH, in the Barony of Iffa and Offa, Co. of Tipperary, and Prov-

L I S nice of Munster: an entire ReetotV : no Church : no Glebe House: a Glebe, of 15 r. Sr, 30 p., very near the site of the old church: The Incumbent lately dead (in 1806), and no Successor yet appointed : there is cure of souls: ancl the duties are noAV performed by the Curate of a neighbouring parish. Lisronagh is in the Diocese of Lismore, and Province of Cashel. It is 3_j m. N. from Clonmell; According to the Ecclesiastical Report, the entire Rectory of Lisronagh may very Avell stand alone ; and a Glebe House ought to be built upon the Glebe. LISSADILL, in the Barony of Carbury, Co. of Sligo, and Province of Con naught. lt is 8 m. N. W. from Sligo. It is situate upon the Sea-coast. LONDONDERRY, or, DERRY, within the County of the City of London- derry, and Province of Ulster : The Hon. .and Right Rev. William Knox, D. D., Lord Bishop, in 1806: a Chapel of Ease, in repair: no Glebe House, or Glebe: The Rev. H. Mardock, the Resident Incumbent, in 1806. Londonderry is in the Diocese of Deny, and Province of Armagh. It is 115 m. N. b. W. from Dublin. The Fairs are holden on the 17th of June, 4th of September, and 17th of October. It has six Post-days in the week. This City sends one Member to Parliament. The Magistrates are a Mayor, Aldermen, Recorder, Chamberlain, two Sheriffs, aud a ToAvn Clerk. It hath also a Military Governor, and Town Major. It was built by the citizens of London, in tbe reign of James the First; and takes its name from having become the property of the TAvelve Trades or Corporations of Lon- don. The family of Pitt take title of Earl from this City ; and the family of Stew- art that of Baron. It is a handsome town, situate upon the River Foyle, and contains about 10,000 inhabitants, whose principal commerce is Avith America, and the West Indies. It is still surrounded Avith Avails, and is the Metropolis of the County. The Military Governor of Londonderry is Commander of Culmore Fort. The celebrated dramatic Avriter, George Farquhar, Avas born here in the year 1678. The Bishoprick of Derry (valued in the King's Books at ,£250. ster- ling) was constituted, according to Dr. Beaufort, in the year 1158: Its greatest length is 47 miles, and its greatest breadth 43, extending into the Counties of An- trim, Donegal, Londonderry, and Tyrone. The Chapter consists of a Dean (see, Templemore), an Archdeacon (see, Dunboe), and three Prebendaries. There are in the city of Londonderry the Cathedral, and a large Palace erected at the expense of Bishop Barnard. It is only 32 miles distant from the remotest part of the Dio- cese. — " St. Columb, of noble extraction, Avas born at Gartan, in the county of Donegal, in the year 521, ancl was educated under St. Finian in the great school of Clonard. The Noblesse of Kinell-conuill (the county of Donegal) granted Dore calgach to their relation St. Columb in the year 535 ; but as the Saint could not at that time be sixteen years old, the foundation of the Abbey cannot be placed before the year 546, when he may be supposed to have founded it for Canons Regular under the Rule of St. Augustin : This Abbey was a daughter of that of St. Peter

LOR and St. Paul at Annagh, and Avas in after times dedicated to St. Columb himself: He is said by some to have made a pilgrimage to the Abbey of Glastonbury, in So mersetshire, ancl there to have concluded his earthly pilgrimage, A. D. 597, in the 76th year of his age : he Avas buried in the Abbey of Hy, but Avas aftenvards re moved to Downpatrick. — The Registry of the Honour of Richmond says, that an Abbey for Nuns osthe Cistertian Order Avas founded at Derry, A. D. 1218, by Turlogh Leinigh O'Neil of Strabane. — A Dominican Friary was founded here in the year 1274 by O'Donell, the younger, Prince of Tyrconnell, at the request of St. Dominick : tbe number of Friars in this House Avas generally 150. There are no remains of this building, which Avas situate on the North side of the city. — Dr. Bourke alone mentions, that the Friars of the Order of St. Francis had a Monastery here."— ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. pp. 84. et seq. LONG, in the Barony of Coshlea, Co. of Limerick, and Province of Mun ster: a V., being one osthe parishes Avhich constitute the Union of Any. LOUGHMOE, in the Barony of Eliogurty, Co. of Tipperary, ancl Province of Munster: a V., valued in the King's Books at £3. .6.. 8 Irish Money; being one of the parishes Avhich constitute the Union of Thurles. LOUGH NEAGH, this great body of water, Avashes the shores osthe Counties of Antrim, Armagh, Down, Londonderry, and Tyrone. According to Dr. Beau fort, it is fifteen miles long, seven broad, and coA-ers 58,200 acres. The River Bann is the only outlet for seven rivers and innumerable streams, that pour their tributary Avaters into this great Inland sea; Avhich, though by far the largest, is by no means the most beautiful of the Irish lakes. The shores are mostly formed either by an inanimate strand, or marshy borders liable to frequent floods; and are, of course, deficient in those \-aried banks and bold promontories, without Avhich such extensive sheets of water cannot haA*c a picturesque effect, unless Avhen the uniformity is broken by frequent Islands of different size ancl character: — but there are only tAvo in this Lake ; a very small one near the mouth of the Blackwater, and Ram Island, Avithin a short distance of the Antrim shore, remarkable only for an ancient Round tower. The vieAVs are more pleasing in Lough Beg, a small Lake, into which these waters again expand, after a course of about a mile through a very contracted channel. The form of Lough Beg, its Islands, some Avooded points of land, Avith intervening lawns ancl rocks, the magnificent Rotunda at Bal lyscullen, and the beautiful lightness of Toome-Bridge, produce the most happy effect. It Avould be unpardonable to omit, that Lough Neagh has been long cele brated for a petrifying quality, which the Avater, or rather (it is said) the soil, possesses on some parts of the Antrim shore. LOUGH OUGHTER, in the Barony of Loughtee, Co. of Cavan, and Prov ince of Ulster. — " About the festival of Christmas, in the year 1237, or in 1249, Clarus Mac Moylin O'Moillchonry, Archdeacon of Elphin, brought the White

Hibern. p. 42. The Church of Lusk consists of two long aisles, divided by a range of seven arches; the East end is fitted up for the use of the parish. Adjoining the West end stands an handsome square steeple, three angles of which are supported by round towers, and near to the fourth angle is one of those ancient round towers, so peculiar to this Kingdom: it is in good preservation, and rises several feet above the battle ments osthe steeple. — The Nunnery, which Avas originally founded for Nuns of the Order of Arroasia, Avas afterwards appropriated to the Priory of All Saints, 3 x

2 L Y S Dublin. The walls ofa Church, said to have been this ancient Nunnery, are still to be seen in Lusk." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 251. LUSMAGH, v. KILMACUNNA. MAG in person. Macromp is in the Diocese of Cloyne, and Province of Cashel. It is 141 m. S. W. from Dublin. The Fairs are holden on the 12th of May, July, Sep tember, and November. It is now inhabited, and kept in good order; and in it, Sir William Penn, the famous Admiral, Avas born. B., the Prebendary (in 1806), Avho has a Stall in the Cathedral: The Vicarage is valued in the King's Books at ,£l7..6..8 Irish Money : a Church, in good order : a Glebe House ; and a Glebe, of 6 acres, near the church: The Rev. Nicholas Ashe, A. B., the Incumbent (in 1806), who has cure of souls, is resident, and discharges the duties in person. Maynooth is in the Dioceses of Dublin ancl Glandelagh, and Province of Dublin. It is ll£ m, W. b. N. from Dublin. It has six Post-days in the Aveek. The Fairs are holden on the 4th of May, 19th of September, and 9th of October. Here isa Charter School for 50 Girls. Near this is Carton House, the superb Mansion of His Grace The Duke of Leinster. The Royal College of St. Patrick, Maynooth, for the education of persons professing the Roman Catholic religion, was instituted by Act of Parliament, in the year 1795. The Building consists of lodging-rooms, schools, a church, library, hall, and different offices, suitable to the accommoda tion of 200 Ecclesiastical Students, besides a President, Vice-President, Dean, Bursar, Professors, ancl Servants : And an extension of one of tbe Avings is far advanced for the reception of 200 additional Students. The Lay College, at Maynooth, Avas established by Private Subscription, in 1802. — " Gerald Earl of Kildare founded a College adjoining this town, in Avhich he placed a Provost, and Vice-Provost, Avith five Priests or FcIIoavs, tAvo Clerks, and three Boys, to pray for his soul, and the soul of his wife; And William, Archbishop of Dublin, on the 6th of October, in the year 1518, granted his especial confirmation." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 333. MAYO, in the Barony of Clonmorris, Co. of Mayo, and Province of Con naught: a R. and V., valued in the King's Books at £3. sterling, being one osthe parishes Avhich constitute the Union of Ballinrobe. Mayo is in the Diocese of Tuam, ancl Province of Tuam. It is 6 m. N. b. E. from Hollymount. This tOAvn, though hoav decayed, appears to have been formerly a large place: and was famous for its University. See, Ballinrobe. — " St. Colman, having resigned the Benedictine Cell of Lindisfarne, in Northumberland, returned into Ireland, A. D. 665, and founded an Abbey of Regular Canons here, under the Invocation of St. Michael. He placed a company of English Monks therein, from Avhom it was called Magio na Sasson, or, Mayo of the English. Here was also a Nunnery."— ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 505. MEELICK, or, MILICK, in the Barony of Longford, Co. of Galavay, and Province of Connaught: a V., valued in the King's Books at <£0..5..0 sterling, being one of the parishes Avhich constitute the Union of Clonfert Meelick is in the Dioceses of Clonfert and Kilmacduagh, and Province of Tuam. During the Avinter months, the Friary Avas surrounded by the inundations osthe river. The Monastery of Milick Avas aftenvards granted to Sir John King, Avho assigned it to the Earl of Clanricarde." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 294. MEELICK, in the Barony of Gallen, Co. of Mayo, and Province of Con naught: a V., being* one osthe parishes Avhich constitute the Union of Killcon duff. It is in the Diocese of Armagh, and Province of Armagh. It is 4\ va. N. W. from Drogheda. It is situate in a beautiful little valley, watered by a rivulet. — " A. D. 1 142, Donough Mac Corvoill or Carrol, Prince of Uriell, erected an Abbey here for Monks of the Cistertian order, Avith which St. Bernard furnished it from his own Abbey of Clairvaux. The Abbot of this Llouse sat as a Baron in Parliament. Here yet remains, in tolerable presentation, a beautiful little Chapel, built of a yelloAvish free-stone, intermixed with red; the entrance to the chapel is through a superb Gothic arch, which on the inside is exquisitely finished ; the East AvindoAV is truly elegant, and on each side are three smaller AvindoAvs, finished in the style of the great arch, Avhich is accurately represented in Wright's Louthiana ; the work of this arch, as well as that of the Avindows, pillars, &c, have still the remains of a profusion of gilding, and painting in variegated colours. Here is also to be seen the ruins of a spacious octagon erec tion, built of a light-grey free-stone, on the top of which Avas a large cistern, from Avbence Avater was conveyed, by means of pipes, to the different offices in the Abbey."— ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. pp. 479. et seq. MENLOUGH, in the Barony of Tiaquin, Co. of Galavay, and Province of Connaught. It is 4\ vn. W. from Castle-Blakeney. A village. MOD of Munster. It is 1 28 ra. W. S. W. from Dublin. It has six Post-days in the Aveek. MITCHELSTOWN,or, STROKESTOWN, in theBarony of Slane, Co. of Meath, ancl Province of Leinster: a R., valued in the King's Books at £9. -3. .0 Irish Money, being one of the parishes Avhich constitute the Union of Syddan. It has no Glebe Land. The duties are performed by The Rev. George Forster (in 1806), at a Salary of ,£100. per annum. See, Toem. MOHAN, in the Barony of FeAvs, Co. of Armagh, and Province of Ulster. MOHILL, in theBarony of Mohill, Co. of Leitrim, and Province of Con naught: a V. : a Church, in good repair: a Glebe House, and a Glebe of 400 acres: The Rev. D. 652 ; many Glebes, Lands, Vassals, Fees, Tythes, &c, were given to this church, Avhich Avas dedicated to the Virgin Mary."— ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 410. MOINTAGLIS, v. MOYNTAGHS. MOIRA, anciently MOIRATH, in the Barony of LoAver Iveagh, Co. of Doavn, and Province of Ulster : a R. : a Church, in good repair : a neAV Glebe House, on 17 acres of Glebe, a quarter of a mile from tbe church : The Rev. C. W. Moore, the Incumbent (in 1806), av1io has cure of souls, and is not resident, by permission, on account of bad health: the duties are discharged by a Resident Curate, at a Salary of £.75. per annum. MOLAHIFFE, hi the Barony of Magunihy, Co. of Kerry, and Province of Munster : a V., being one of the parishes Avhich constitute the Union of Killbonane. Molahiffe is in the Diocese of Ardfert and Aghadoe, and Provinceof Cashel. It is 4 m. N. E. frora MilltOAvn. It is situate upon the River Mang. See, Killbonane.

MON MOLANA, ISLAND, off the Barony of Decies mitten Drum, Co. of Water ford, and Province of Munster. It is two miles and an half North from Youghal. It is a small Island, and AA*as anciently called, The Island of St. Molanfide, and also, Darinis.— " St. Molanfide founded an Abbey here in the Sixth century, for Canons Regular, and w*as the first Abbot. On the Suppression, Queen Elizabeth granted this Abbey and its possessions to Sir Walter Raleigh, Avho assigned it to the Earl of Cork. The Nave and Choir of this Abbey remain entire, adjoining which are several ruinous Walls, and the erection, built in the Gothic style, appears to be very ancient."— ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 695. MOLCONR1AGHE, v. MONEGEA. MOLESKAR, or, MOLYSCAR, in the Barony of Fertullagh, Co. of West Meath, and Province of Leinster : a R., valued in the King's Books at <£0.. 10.. 10 Irish Money, and united by Act of Council, time not known (though it is probable, that the Act must have been destroyed by the fire which consumed the Records in the Council office in 1711, as there are documents that seem to indicate its having passed about that time), to the Rectories of Carrick, and Lynne : a Church, in good repair: no Glebe House, or Glebe : The Rev. Robert Evans, the Incumbent (in 1806), who has cure of souls, but is non-resident, on account of Infirmity ; the duties are discharged by a Resident Curate, at a Salary of £65. per annum. It is 3f 111. S. from Mullingar. The parishes in the Union of Moleskar are contiguous; that of Moleskar containing 935 acres. Itis situate upon Lough Ennel. Moleskar is in the Diocese of Meath, and Province of Armagh. MOLL GRANGE, v, BURNCHURCH. MONAGHAN, in the Barony of Monaghan, Co. of Monaghan, and Province of Ulster : a R. ancl V., valued in the King's Books at ,£3.. 6.. 8 sterling : a Church, in good condition: no Glebe House; 24 acres of Glebe, half a mile distant from the church: The Rev. Robert Montgomery, the Incumbent (in 1 806), who has cure of souls ; the duties are discharged by a Resident Curate, at a Salary of £.75. per annum. Monaghan is in the Diocese of Clogher, and Province of Armagh. It is 62 m. N. N. W. from Dublin. The Fairs are holden on Easter-- Tuesday, 28th of May, 12th of July, 18th of August, first Tuesday in October, and 21st of November. It gives title of Baron to the family of Blayney. It has six Post-days in the Aveek. Itis governed by a Sovereign. — " Here Ave find an ancient Abbey, of which St. Moeldodius, the son of Aedh, Avas Abbot. — Phelim Mac Brien, &c, sounded, on the site of this ancient Abbey, a Monastery for Conventual Franciscans, Avhich Avas granted, at the Suppression, to EdAvard Withe, and a Castle has been since erected on the site by Edward Lord Blayney."—Arch daWs Monast. Hibern. p. 585. MONAINCHA, in the Barony of Ikerin, Co. of Tipperary, and Province of Munster. It is 3 m. S. E. from Roscrea. It is situate almost in the centre of the great Bog of Monela. — " The Monastery of Monaincha Avas originally an Abbey

MON of Culdean Monks, under the Invocation of St. Columba, Avhose Festival was formerly celebrated there on the 15th of June. The situation chosen by these Religious was very singular. The Island, whereon the Monastery is built, consists of about two acres of dry ground; all the surrounding parts being a soft morass, scarcely accessible by human feet, and yet, on this Isle stands the remains of a beautiful edifice ; not large, but constructed in so fine a style, and with such materials, as excites our wonder Iioav they could have been transported thither. The length of the Church is 44 feet, the width about 18 ; the arches of the Choir and the Western portal are semicircular, and adorned Avith a variety of curious mouldings ; the WindoAvs were contrasted arches, such as appear over the West entrance to the church of St. Edmund's Bury, in Suffolk, but they are decaying, and some are fallen doAvn. The antiquity of this Monastery is indisputable ; for it is mentioned by Giraldus Cambrensis, who came into Ireland in 1185, as Preceptor ancl Secre tary to King John, then Earl of Morton. He says this Island borders upon North Munster and the confines of Leinster, and that there a feAV Culdees, or Colidei, did devoutly serve God. To tbe East of the Abbey Church is a small Oratory, but no vestige of Monastic dwellings can be found on this Isle, save only the Abbey and the Abbot's room adjoining it, which Avas over the Cellars, and but small ; whatever others might have been, were probaly formed of wood, and in the lapse of many centuries have ceased to exist. Superstition established an opinion, so early as the age of Giraldus, that no person could die in this Isle let his malady be ever so extreme, or his fate ever so urgent : the merits of the Patron Saint and those of his Religious, secured this privilege to an Isle so favour ed, and hence it acquired the appellation of Insula Viventium, or, The Island of the Living. This Legendary celebrity brought, from tbe remotest parts, innu merable Pilgrims, to expiate their sins at the altar of St. Columba, and a gainful trade was carried on for more than Ten centuries; which enabled the monks to improve their Abbey and add such decorations as the fashion and taste osthe clay required : for we are not to suppose, that the present church is the same as the original, Avhich Avas erected in the Seventh century : that Avas probably of Avood, in Avhich state it continued till the invasion of the Ostmen, Avhen a neAv style of Architecture commenced, and Monaincha Avas constructed of more durable materials. However, the salubrity and supernatural power of the Isle Avas not so great as to prevent the emigration of its Religious inhabitants to the main land. They found the noxious vapours of the surrounding marshes ancl swamps highly injurious to their constitutions, and tbey, as Ware informs us, fixed their residence at Corbally ; Avhere is at this day, in good preservation, a small neat Chapel of a cruciform shape, Avith narroAV slits for windows, and many other particulars indicating a respectable antiquity. By an inquisition taken, A. D. 1568, it was found that the Monastery of Canons Regular of the Virgin Mary, in the Island of the Living, otherwise called Inchenebo, was seized of the folloAving lands ;

M O N the Island, Avhich contained three acres of moor, wherein were tAvo Chapels ; and near the island, a Village, called Corballi, in which the Prior and Convent dAvelt, where also Avas a Church, formerly the church of the Priory and Parish, and is still the parish church ; in this village Avere eight waste cottages, and the land Avhich belonged to the priory consisted of 180 acres of arable and pasture, annual value 30s. ; 140 of unprofitable, and 16 acres of Avood ancl under- Avood, annual value ,£0..2..8, &c. In the 28th of Queen Elizabeth, this Abbey was granted to Sir Lucas Dillon," — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. pp. 667. et seq. MONANIMY, in the Barony of Fermoy, Co. of Cork, and Province of Munster : a R. and V., being one of the parishes Avhich constitute the Union of Coole. Monanimy is in the Diocese of Cloyne, and Province of Cashel. It is 3 m. N. E. from MalloAv. It is situate near the River Blackxvater. See, Coole. — " No mention is made by any of our Avriters of this Commandery ; but at Mo nanimy Ave find an ancient Castle, Avith the traces of several large buildings round it." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 75. MONASTERBOYCE, in the Barony of Ferrard, Co. of Louth, and Province of Leinster : a Curacy, being one of the parishes Avhich constitute the Union of Dunleer. Monasterboyce is in the Diocese of Armagh, and Province of Armagh. It is 2-j m. E. S. E. from Collon. This parish contains 1000 acres of land. See, Dunleer " Here we find a Religious house, Avhich Avas anciently called Monaster- Bute, being founded by St. Bute, or Boetius, the son of Bronagh. Here are the ruins of two small chapels ; and although nothing remarkable is to be seen in their structure, yet do they evince the great antiquity of this foundation ; near the West end of one of these chapels is a Round toAver, 1 10 feet high, beautifully diminishing, in the manner ofa Tuscan pillar, from a base of 18 feet : its circum ference is seventeen yards, and the w*all, built ofa slaty stone of which the sur rounding hills are composed, is three feet six inches thick, the door is five feet six inches in height, twenty-two inches in Avidth, and six feet from the present level of the ground, it is arched ancl built of free-stone, as are the Avindows of the chapels ; in the inside the diameter is nine feet, and above tbe door it is divided into five stories, by rings of stone slightly projecting. — There are tAvo large crosses on the South side of the church, the principal one is said to be of an entire stone, and is called St. Boyne's Cross, which is the most ancient Religious relique now extant in Ireland; the ornamental figures on it are rudely engraven, ancl at once shoAV the uncivilized age in Avhich they Avere executed ; there is also an inscrip tion on this cross in the old Irish character, equally inelegant Avith the figures, some letters of Avhich appear and evidently form the Avoid Muredach, Avho Avas for some time King of Ireland, and died A. D. 534, about one hundred years after the arrival of St. Patrick. This Abbey continues to be a Burial-place of note."— ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 490.

At the general suppression, this Abbey was granted to George Lord Audley, who assigned the same to Adam Loftus, Viscount Ely. It afterwards came into the Earl of Drogheda's family, by whom it Avas beautifully repaired, still externally Avearing the venerable appearance of an Abbey, which appellation it continues to support, and Moore Abbey is now the elegant seat of the present Earl."— ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 333. MONASTERNENAGH, in the Barony of Poblebrien, Co. of Limerick, and Province of Munster : a V. : no Church : no Glebe House, or Glebe : The Rev. D. 1148 or 1151, by O'Brien, who furnished it Avith Monks of the Cistertian Order from the Abbey of Mellifont, in the County of Louth. The Cell of Feal was afterwards annexed to this House. The Abbot Avas a Baron of Parliament. This Abbey, and its posses sions, were granted to Sir Henry Wallop, Knight." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 432. MONASTERNICALLIAGH, in the Barony of Small County, Co. of Limer- ick, and Province of Munster — " Here was formerly a Nunnery for Canonesses of the Order of St. Augustin, dedicated to St. Catherine. MONEMOINTER, or, BALLYCLOGHY, in the Barony of Gualtiere, Co. of WaTerford, and Province of Munster: a Rectory entire, valued in the King's Books at _£l..7..4 Irish Money, and constituting with the Rectories of Kilmac league, and Kilmacomb, and part of tbe Rectories of Kilmeaden, and Reisk, the Corps of the Chancellorship of Waterford, having probably been united at the same time Avhen the Deanery Avas established, and Avhich is valued in the King's Books at £.10. Irish Money : no Church : a Glebe House, in Trinity parish, in the City of Waterford, belonging to the Chancellor: four Glebes: one, of 15 a. 2r. 15 p., at Kilmacomb, close to the site osthe old church: the second, of 8 a. 1 r. 21 p., at Kilmacleague, close to the site of the old church; and the third and fourth, of about 6 acres in each, at Reisk, one of them being close to the site of the old church, ancl the other about a mile distant from it : each of these Glebes are very distant from the other: The Hon. and Rev. Hibern. p. 696. MOUNT BELLEW, in the Barony of Tiaquin, Co. of Galavay, and Province of Connaught. It is 5 m. N. W. from Castle Blakeney. A village. D., see, The Transactions osthe Royal Irish Academy, vol. i. p'. 3. Antiquities. MOUNT CHARLES, in the Barony of Boylagh and Bannogh, Co. of Done gal, and Province of Ulster. It is 3 m.
