TEM TEHALLON, in the Barony of Monaghan, Co. of Monaghan, and Province of Ulster: a R. and V., valued in the King's Books at £6. sterling: a Church, in good condition: a Glebe House: 40 acres of Glebe, very near the church .- The Rev. Edward Stanley, the Incumbent (in 1806), who has cure of souls, is resident, and discharges the duties. Tehallon is in the Diocese of Clogher, and Province of Armagh. Itis 2fm. E. N. E. from Monaghan. — "St. Killian was Bishop of Tegtalain, or Teachtally, in Orgiella, and his Festival is holden on the 27th of May."— ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 386. TEINAGH, v. TYNAGH. TELTOWN, v. KILLALTON. TEMAGHCREMAY, v. TECKMACRAVEN. TEMPLE ADIGAN, in the Barony of Bantry, Co. of Wexford, and Province of Leinster: a V., being one of the parishes Avhich constitute the Union of St. Mary's, NeAV Ross. TEMPLE-BELAGH, in the Barony of Condons and Clangibbon, Co. of Cork, and Province of Munster : a R., valued in the King's Books at £3. sterling, being a Particle in the Union of Kilmacdonough. TEMPLE BODANE, alias DRONMOYRE, in the Barony of Barrymore, Co. of Cork, and Province of Munster : a V., valued in the King's Books at £2. sterling : no Church : no Glebe House : a Glebe, of 9 acres : The Rev. TOBERGLORY, in the Barony of Lecale, Co. of Doavn, and Province of Ul ster. — " Sir John de Courcey founded an Abbey to the honour of St. Thomas the Martyr near this well, which adjoins the toAvn of DoAvnpatrick, betAveen tAvo roads, the one leading to Crems, ancl the other to the Grange of Saul. TRIM, in the Barony of Navan, Co. of Meath, ancl Province of Leinster: a V., Avith the R. of Newtown, valued in the King's Books at _£65..6..8 Irish Money, and Episeopally united, on every vacancy, time immemorial, to the R. of Tub berville, and the Curacies of Kilcooley, Sunlockstown, and Tullaghanogue : a Church, (dedicated to St. Mary), in Trim, lately re-built, and now in complete repair : a Glebe House, on a Glebe of 3^ acres, near the church : and another Glebe, of 182 acres, about one mile distant from the former: The Rev. The Rectory of NeAV tOAvn Avas purchased by the Board of First Fruits, for the better support osthe Vicar of St. Mary's of Trim: And, according to the Ecclesiastical Report, it appears, that Tubberville, SunlockstoAvn, and Kilcooley, might better unite with neighbouring parishes of small Income. — " Here we find many Religious foundations ; and Father Colo*an informs us, that, so early as the year 432, St. Patrick founded this Abbey of Canons Regular, dedicated to the Virgin Mary, and built on a piece of ground given for that purpose by Fethlemid, the son of Laoghaire and grandson of Niall. The steeple, usually called The YelloAV Steeple, was a lofty, handsome, square toAver, one half of Avhich Avas demolished by Oliver Cromwell, against whom it held out

T R O a considerable time as a garrison. — The Gray Friary was dedicated to St. Bonaven ture, and in general Avas called, The Observantine Friary of Trim ; it Avas originally founded by King John; though others say by the family of Plunket This Friary is totally demolished, and the present Session-house is erected on part osthe ancient foundation. Father Richard Plunket, who Avrote an Irish Dictionary, now in the Public Library of Dublin, resided in this convent — The Dominican Friary, situated near the gate leading to Athboy, was founded in honour of the Virgin Mary, A. D. 1263, by Geoffrey de Geneville, Lord of Meath. — The Priory of Crossbeareis Avas dedicated to St. John the Baptist; one of the Bishops of Meath was said to be the founder, and his successors in that See Avere great benefactors to this Priory. We are told, that this Avas a truly magnificent building: ancl it is probable, that tbe Parliaments of Trim were holden in the great hall of this house : the walls are still in being. — Here Avas a Convent of Nuns. — There Avas an ancient Church here, called The Church osthe Grecians ; which may be some proof that the Grecians of old made a settlement in this kingdom. — We also find, in the parish church of St. Patrick in this town, a Perpetual Chantry of three Priests."— ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. pp. 575. et seq. TRIMLESTOWN, in the Barony of Navan, Co. of Meath, ancl Province of Leinster: a Chapelry. It is in the Diocese of Meath, ancl Province of Arm a°h. It is 2 in. W. N. This magnificent and beautiful edifice, in the form of a cross ancl of a considerable extent, was built of a blackish stone, and the steeple was remarkable, being an octagon erected on the top of a square tower, which, though mutilated, Avas, in the year 1780, 74 feet high, the columns Avere also octagon Avith plain capitals. Here Avas a considerable Monastery ; Ave cannot learn by Avhom it Avas founded. Hibern. p. 574. TUAIM MUSGRAIGHE, in the Barony of Muskerry, Co. of Cork, and Prov ince of Munster. D., Lord Arch bishop of Tuam, in 1810 : a V., united by Act of Council, in 1788, to the Vicarages of Addergoole, Belclare, Kilbennan, Kilconla, and Liskeevy: no Parish Church; the Service being always performed in the Cathedral Church of St. Mary's, Tuam: a Glebe House, in good repair; a Glebe, of 16 acres, in the parish of Tuam, 10 acres in Kilbennan, 2 acres in Belclare, and 15 acres in Kilconla: The Rev. Ro bert Warren, the Incumbent (in 1806), avIio has cure of souls, is resident, and has a Faculty. Tuam is in the Diocese of Tuam, ancl Province of Tuam. It is 93 m. W. b. N. from Dublin. According to Dr. Beaufort, this Bishoprick (valued in the King's Books at £'50. sterlino*) Avas established early in the Sixth century, and is considerably the largest in the Kingdom, extending over a great part of the Counties of Gahvay, and Mayo, and including a part of Roscommon. It is upwards of 60 miles long, and 50 broad. With this See the Bishoprick of Ar da gh is holden in Commendam. The Chapter consists of a Dean, a Provost, an Archdeacon, ap-1 3 Prebendaries. The 4 s

TUB Deanery alone is in the patronage osthe CroArn; 79 parishes are in the Bishop's Gift; and 10 are united to the Wardenship of Galway. The Constitution of that large and ancient Collegiate Church is unique in this kingdom; the Warden and three Assisting Vicars being elected by the Mayor and Corporation ; the Warden annually, and the Vicars for life. In the little City of Tuam there is a very neat but small Cathedral, Avhich is also the parish church. The Bishop's Palace is a large antique fabric ; from whicli no part of this extensive Diocese is 50 miles distant. The extent of the Union of Tuam is about 8 miles in length, ancl about 6 miles in breadth : Liskeevy is distant from the other parishes about 5 miles. — " We are told that an Abbey was founded here, so early as the year 487, under the Invocation of the Virgin Mary. St. Jarlath is said to have made it a Cathedral in the beginning of the Sixth century ; and it is also said that a City Avas built here in honour of this exemplary Bishop. His remains were preserved at Tuam, in a Chapel, called Temple-na-scrin, i. e., The Church of the Shrine. — The Priory of St. John the Baptist Avas founded about the year 1140, by Tirdelvac O'Connor, king of Ireland. We cannot say to Avhat Order this House did belong, but find that it Avas granted to Richard Earl of Clanrickard.— The Abbey of the Holy Trinity Avas sounded by one of tbe family of Burgh, either in the reign of King John, or in the beginning of King Henry III, for Premonstre Canons." — Arch daWs Monast. TUBRID, in the Barony of Iffa and Offa, Co. of Tipperary, and Province of Munster : a R. and V. : the Rectory being the Corps of the Deanery of Lismore, i

T U L Avhich is valued in the King's Books at £13. sterling: no Glebe House: a Glebe, of 29 acres, in the parish ofTubrid; a Parcel of Land, in tbe parish of Lismore, belonging lo the Deanery, ancl containing 469 a. 2 r. 2 p. ; and a few Perches of Land, in tbe parish of Lismore, on which the ruins of a Deanery House stand : these Lands are not contiguous : Tubrid Glebe being very near the church, and 12 miles from Lismore Cathedral, and about 14 miles from the Deanery Laud, which is near 2 miles from the Cathedral of Lismore : The Rev. John Scott, the Incumbent (in 1 806) : It is alleged, that the Dean of Lismore has not cure of souls ; but the Charter osthe Deanery, which is a Peculiar, as well as every thing relating to the Cathedral of Lismore, is lost; and no document Avhatsoeyer, concerning this establishment, is forthcoming. The Dean resides in tbe parish of Lismore, Avithin half a mile osthe Cathedral: the Preacher, who preaches the turns of the Dean and Chapter of Lismore, in the Cathedral of Lismore, has a Salary of Fifty guineas per annum: he resides in Lismore: The Vicarage, valued in the King's Books at £5..3..0 sterling, Avas Episeopally united, in the year 1786, Avhen the present In cumbent took possession, to the Vicarage of Ballybacon; and to these, the Vic arage of Tullaghorton Avas Episeopally united, on the 21st of June 1804 : a Church, in repair, in the parish ofTubrid : a Glebe House, in the parish of Tubrid: three Glebes; one, of 27 a. 2 r. 36 p., in Tubrid, a feAV perches from tbe church; another, of 4 a. 1 r. 22 p., in Ballybacon, adjacent to the site of theoldchurch : and the third, of 0 a. 3 r. 20 p., in Tullaghorton, close to the site of the old church: these Glebes are not contiguous : the Glebe of Tubrid being distant from that of Ballybacon about three miles, and from that of Tullaghorton about tAvo miles; and Ballybacon Glebe is distant about tAvo miles from that of Tullaghorton : The Rev. Robert Draper, the Incumbent (in 1806), Avho has cure of souls, and resides in the City of Waterford, Avhere he fills the office of Surrogate : the duties are performed by a Curate, Avho resides in the Glebe House at Tubrid, at a Salary of ,£75. per annum. Tubrid is in the Diocese of Lismore, and Province of Cashel. It is 4 m. S. W. b. S. from Cahir. The parishes in the Union ofTubrid are contiguous; that ofTubrid containing 7215 acres of land. According to the Ecclesiastical Report, the Vicarage of Tubrid might stand very well alone. TULLAMORE, or, KILBRIDE, in the Barony of BallicoAven, King's County, and Province of Leinster : a Chapelry : a Chapel, built by the Charleville Family, and is used as the parish church : no Glebe House, but a situation for a Manse* has been granted by Lord Charleville, and the forms of law hive not yet been gone through : The Rev. TULLY, partly in the Barony of Ophaly, and partly in the Barony of Kilcullen, Co. of Kildare, and Province of Leinster : a Preceptory or Commandery, holden with the Bishoprick of Kildare, as part of the Corps thereof: no Church : no Glebe House, or Glebe Land : The Lord Bishop of Kildare is Preceptor or Rector, having cure of souls in the parishes of Tully, and Coglanstown, ancl jn other places appurtenant thereto: the duties are performed by his Licensed Curate, The Rev. John Williamson, Avho is resident in the contiguous parish of Kildare, at a Salary of ,£30. per annum. Tully is in the Diocese of Kildare, and Province of Dublin. It is 1 rn. S. from Kildare. The Fairs are holden on the 1st of January, and 27th of July. This parish contains 2845 acres of land, by estimation. According to tbe Ecclesiastical Report, the Preceptory of Tully consists of Tully, CoglanstoAvn, Doneny, and DavidstoAvn: this Preceptory being the Corps of the Bishoprick of Kildare, but the Bishop had not, in 1806, been able to procure full information, Avhether it possessed other Denominations. And it is recommended, that the Bishop should be dispossessed of these tythes, as his enjoyment of them deprives the Incumbents osthe lespectiA'e parishes, in which they are situate, of the very means of residence. To effect this purpose, some proper compensation may be suggested. See, Feighcullen, Great Connel, and Pollardstown. TULLY-AGHNISH, or, TULLAGHAGNISH, in the Barony of Kilmacrenan, Co. of Donegal, and Province of Ulster: a R. ancl V., valued in tbe King's Books at,£]0. sterling: a Church: no Glebe House; a large tract of Glebe, in conveniently situated for the residence of the Clergyman, being far removed from Rathmelton, Avhere the church stands : The Rev. Accord ing to the Diocesan Returns, it appears that, " the parish of Tully-Aghnish, in the Presentation of the College of Dublin, has been holden for time immemorial under this title and denomination, as a single parish by a single Clerk, having one Church only, and Parish Officers as for one Church: although tbere were informer times two distinct parishes, but still contiguous, and noted in the Taxation-Book of the Court of Exchequer under the titles of Rectory and Vicarage of Tully-Fern, and Rectory and Vicarage of Aghnish, Avith a separate Taxation to each (each being valued at £10. sterling). But Avhen, by what authority, and in what man ner they were united, does not appear. The Minister is constantly resident." — " St. Columb founded an Abbey at Tulachdubglaisse, which is now a parish church."— ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. -p. 105. <■">

TUMNA, or, TOEMONIA, in the Barony of Boyle, Co. of Roscommon, and Province of Connaught : a V., valued in the King's Books at £\. sterling, being one of the parishes Avhich constitute the Archdeaconry of Elphin. T Y N and the Appurtenances and Tythes adjacent to the Friary, valued at 10s. sterling annually. TY-VOURNEY GERRAN, in the Barony of Corcaguinny, Co. of Kerry, and Province of Munster. It is 8| m. S. W. from Dingle. ULLOE, in the Barony of Coonagh, Co. of Limerick, and Province of Mun ster : a Vicarage, valued in the King's Books at £J2..1..0 sterling: no Church: no Glebe House : two Glebes; one, of 10a. 1 r. 24 p., ancl the other, of 25 a. 1 r. 6 p. : Tbe Rev. UPHAM, in the Barony of Middle Third, Co. of Tipperary, and Province of Munster; in the parish of Killenaule. It is 1^ m. S. b. E. from Killenaule. See, Killenaule. i

URN UREGARE, or, OWRGARE, in the Barony of Coshma, Co. of Limerick, and Province of Munster: a V., valued in the King's Books at £6. .3. .4 sterling : no Church : no Glebe House, or Glebe: The Rev. URGLIN, in the Barony of Catherlogh, Co. of Carloav, and Province of Leinster: aR., valued in the King's Books at £5. .6. .8 Irish Money, and Epis eopally united, ever since the year 1713, to the R. of Grangeforth, and, in 1803, to the Impropriate Cure of Killerick: a Church, in repair, in the parish of Urglin: no Glebe House, or Glebe : The Rev. Benjamin Hobart, the Incumbent (in 1806), who has cure of souls, and partly from Avant of accommodation, and partly as Sur rogate of the Diocese, he resides in Carlow, and discharges the duties in person. Urglin is in the Diocese of Leighlin, ancl Province of Dublin. It is 2\ m. E. N. E. from Carlow. The parishes in the Union of Urglin are contiguous ; the contents of Urglin, and Grangeforth, being 3040 acres. URLARE, in the Barony of Costello, Co. of Mayo, and Province of Con naught. — " One of the family of Nangle founded a Monastery here for Dominican Friars, and dedicated it to St. Thomas. This family afterwards took the name of Costello, ancl became Lords of the Barony ; The followers of St. Dominick seated themselves here in the year 1430, Avithout a licence from the Pope, but tbey ob tained one from Eugene IV, avIio made a grant of the same, by a Bull bearing date the 18th of March, 1434. Urlare, or in Irish, Orlare, Avhich signifies an Area, is in a retired situation, and Avas therefore appointed for the general recep tion of Novices throughout the Province of Connaught. We are told, that, in an cient times, there Avas a ToAvn here, but at present there is not a vestige of one to be seen and the ruins of the Abbey alone preserve this place from total oblivion. On the dissolution of Monasteries, this Friary Avas granted to Lord Dillon." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 510. URLINGFORD, in the Barony of Gallmoy, Co. of Kilkenny, and Provinceof Leinster: a R, and V. : no Church : no Glebe: The Rev. The Dean and Chapter of Ossory the Rectors and Vicars : the duties are performed by a Curate, at a Salary of £.10. per annum. Urlingford is in the Diocese of Ossory, and Province of Dublin. It is 9f m. S. W. from Durrow. The Fairs are holden on the 12th of May, 15th of August, and 12th of October. URNEY, v. CAVAN. URNEY, in the Barony of Strabane, Co. of Tyrone, and Province of Ulster: a R. and V., valued in the King's Books at £\3..6..8 sterling: a Church, in repair: a Glebe House, on a Glebe of 60 acres, near the church; and another Glebe, of £05 acres, one mile from the church: The Rev. Robert FoAvler, the Incumbent

V A S (in 1806), who has cureof souls, and occasionally discharges the duties, assisted by a Curate. Urney is in the Diocese of Derry, and Province of Armagh. It is 2 m. S. S. W. from Strabane. It is situate on the River Foyle. USK, in the Barony of Narragh and Reban, Co. of Kildare, and Province of Leinster ; a R. and V., valued in the King's Books at ,£0.. 12..0 Irish Money, being one of the parishes Avhich constitute the Union of Dunlavan. Usk is in the Dioceses of Dublin and Glandelagh, and Province of Dublin. It is 4^va. S. from Kilcullen-Bridge. The Fairs are holden on the Thursday before the 12th of May, and the first Thursday and Friday in October. See, Dunlavan. USKEANE, in the Barony of Lower Ormond, Co. of Tipperary, and Province of Munster: a V-, valued in the King's Books at <£l. sterling, being one of the parishes which constitute the Union of Ballingarry. Uskeane is in the Diocese of Killaloe, and Province of Cashel. It is 2 m. E. b. N. from Burresokeane. See, Ballingarry. USKECHAOIN, in the Barony of Inishowen, Co. of Donegal, and Province of Ulster. — " An Abbey was founded here by St. Columb, which is now a Chapel in the Diocese of Derry, according to Colgan." — ArchdaWs Monast, Hibern. p. 105. V. T7ALENTIA, or, KILLMORE, ISLAND, off the Barony of Iveragh, Co. of Kerry, and Province of Munster: a R. and V., being one of the parishes Avhich constitute the Union of Dromod. Valentia is in the Diocese of Ardfert and Aghadoe, and Province of Cashel. It is 29 ra. S. W. from Milltown. See, Dromod. The Island of Valentia is situate in the Atlantic Ocean, and is about five miles in length : it is a fertile tract, and is esteemed the granary of the Country. This Island forms one side of a fine Harbour, the sea running between it and the main, like a river, which is in most places about half a mile broad, and ofa sufficient depth for vessels to sail through at any time of the tide. Oliver CromAvell had forts erected upon both ends of it, which have gone to ruin since his time. It now belongs to The Earl of Shelburne, by whom it was purchased of the family of Annesley, to which it gives title of Viscount, by creation, on the llth of March 1621. VALE OF ANGELS, v. BANGOR. VASTINA, v. CASTLETOWN KINDELANE.

W A L VENTRY, in the Barony of Corcaguinny, Co. of Kerry, and Province of Munster: a R. and V. r no Church: no Glebe House : a Glebe in three divisions, one of them being close to the old church, and making together 4 a. 3 r. 25 p. : The Rev. Samuel Colliss, the Incumbent (in 1806), who has cure of souls, and is Curate to Killeiny and the adjoining parishes, in one of which he resides : The duties are performed by the Curate of Dingle, at a Salary of £l2. per annum. Ventry is in the Diocese of Ardfert and Aghadoe, and Province of Cashel.' It is 4^ m. W. from Dingle. It is situate on a Harbour, to .vhich it gives name, on tbe Atlantic Ocean. According to the Ecclesiastical Report, this Benefice is too small to afford the means of comfort to a Resident Incumbent. VILLAGRIFFIN, v. BALLYGRIFFIN. VILLAMUNEEN, v. BALLYMOREEN. VILLARAILE, t*. RAYLESTOWN. VILLIERSTOWN, in the Barony of Decies without Drum, Co. of Water ford, and Province of Munster; in the parish of Aglish: a Chapel of Ease, founded by The Earl of Grandison : The Rev. Harris Oldfield, the Incumbent (in 1806), has not cure of souls, and resides at Drumana, Avithin half a mile of the Chapel, and performs the duties in person. Villierstown is in the Diocese of Lismore, and Province of Cashel. It is 7 m. N. W. b. W. from Dungarvan. It is situate near the River Blackwater. VIRGINIA^ in the Barony of Castleraghan, Co. of Cavan, and Province of Ulster. It is 40^ m. N. W. from Dublin. The Fairs are holden on the 9th of July, and 21st of November. It has six Post-days in the week. It is situate on Lough Ramor. VOW FERRY, in the Barony of Coleraine, Co. of Londonderry, and Prov ince of Ulster. It is 2\ vn. N. from Kilrea. A village, where is a Ferry across the River Bann. w. WADDISTOWN, in the Barony of Middle Third, Co. of Tipperary, and Province of Munster : a R. It is in the Diocese of Cashel, and Province of Cashel. It is 5\ va. S. b. E. from Cashel, WALLSTOWN, in the Barony of Fermoy, Co. of Cork, and Province of Munster : a R. and V., valued in the King's Books at £6. sterling, being one of the parishes which constitute the Union of Coole, Wallstown is in the Diocese V

WAT of Cloyne, and Province of Cashel. It is 3 to. E. b. S. from Doneraile. , See, Coole. WALTERSTOWN, in the Barony of Ophaly, Co. of Kildare, and Province of Leinster: a R., valued in the King's Books at £3. Irish Money, being one, of the parishes which constitute the Union of Lackagh. Walterstown is in the Dio cese of Kildare, and Province of Dublin. It is 3-j m. S. S. W. from Kildare. See, Lackagh. WARING'S-POINT, v. WARREN'S-POINT. WARINGSTOWN, in the Barony of Lower Iveagh, Co. of Down, and Prov 'nce of Ulster. It is 2f m, S. b. E. from Lurgan. The site of the parish church of Donoughcloney was changed hither, in 1681. The Linen manufacture is carried on A*ery extensively here. WARREN'S-POINT, or, WARING'S-POINT, in the Barony of Upper Iveagh, Co. of Doavn, and Province of Ulster. It is 56 m. N. from Dublin. It has six Post-days in the Aveek. It is situate upon the Bay of Carlingsord. WATERFORD, Avithin the County of the City of Waterford, ancl Province of Munster: a City, in which are the folloAving parishes, viz, St. John's : The Church is demolished. St. Michael's : The Church is demolished. St. Olave's: a Church, in repair: a small House, belonging to tbe Dean. St. Patrick's, a Prebend, valued in the King's Books at £8. Irish Money : a Church, in repair. St. Feter's: The Church is demolished. St. Stephen's: The Church is demolished. Trinity, with the Chapels of The Dean and St. James, Avithin the Cathe- dral, each valued in tbe King's Books at ,£14. Irish Money : The Cathedral Church, in repair: a Deanery House. The Parishes of Trinity, St. Michael's, and St Olave's, are all Within the City of Waterford, and make about two-thirds of it: they are united to the entire Rectories of Kilburne, and Kilcaragh, ancl part osthe Rectories of Kilmeaden, and Reisk, constituting the Corps of the Deanery of Waterford, which is valued in the King's Books at £'20. Irish Money : and to Avhich Corps, tbe entire Rectory of Kill oteran Avas last Episeopally united, on the 22d of December 1804, when the pre sent Dean became Incumbent; and it appears, that it has been united in the same manner, for time immemorial : two Glebes; one, of 376 a. 3 r. 10 p., belonging to the Deanery, at Ballycasheen, in the parish of Kilburne, with several Cabbins on the land: the other, of 17 acres, at Kilcaragh; these Glebes are distant from each other about two miles : The Rev. Usher Lee, A. M., the Dean (in 1806), who has cure of souls, is resident in the Deanery House, and discharges the duties in person, assisted by his three Curates, who all reside within the Union, viz, The Curate of

WAT the Cathedral, at a Salary of £75.; of St. Olave's, at £50.; and of Killoteran, at ,£50. per annum. The Dean and Chapter of Waterford have the Tythes of Trinity parish in common. There are no Tythes from the other tAvo City parishes. The parishes in this Union are all contiguous; the remotest of them not being sour miles distant from the City of Waterford.— The parishes of St. Peter, St.Patrick,St Stephen.andSt.John, are all contiguous, and comprehend about one-third osthe Avhole city of Waterford : they constitute the Corps of the Archdeaconry, Avhich is valued in the King's Books at £6. Irish Money, and were probably united at the same time when the Deanery was established : a Glebe, of a few perches, behind the church of St. Patrick : The Rev. George LeAvis Fleury, LL. D„ the Incumbent (in 1806), Avho has cure of souls, is resident in the city, ancl performs the duties in person. According to the Ecclesiastical Report, the value of these four Livings is under £.200. per annum, : and are conceived to be of too small value to afford comfort to the Incumbent. — There is also a French Church in the City of Waterford, endoAved by Government Avith ,£50. per annum : of which The Rev. Peter Augustus Franquefort is Incum bent (in 1806) : has not cure of souls : is resident, and performs the duties in per son : It has neither Glebe House, or Glebe Land. — Waterford is in the Diocese of Waterford, and Province of Cashel. The Hon. and Right Rev. PoAver French le Poer, D- D. andWTL. D., Lord Bishop of Waterford and Lismore, in 1802. It is 74^- m. S. S. W. from Dublin. It has six Post-days in the Aveek. The Fairs are holden on the 4th of May, 24th of June, and 25th of October. This City sends one Member to Parliament; the Electors being, Freemen and Freeholders. It Avas originally built in the year 879, but destroyed, in 981 : It was considerably enlarged by Earl Strongbow, in 1171; and still further, in the reign of King Henry the Seventh, who granted clivers privileges to the citizens. King Richard the Second landed, and Avas crowned here, in 1399- In 1690, King James the Second embarked from hence for France, after the Battle of the Boyne. King William the Third resided here tAvice, and confirmed its Privileges. Here is a Charter School, for 60 Boys. The Members of the Corporation consist of a Mayor, Recorder, two Sheriffs, 18 Aldermen, and 19 Assistants, a Town Clerk, Coroner, Clerk of tbe Crown and Peace, Mareschal, Searcher, Public Notary, Water-Bailiff, SAVord-Bearer, four Serjeants at Mace, and other Officers. The Privileges of their Charter are very extensive. The City of Waterford is well built, and contains about 35,000 souls. It stands on the South side of the River Suir, which is embanked by a very noble Quay, extending the whole leno-th of the Town: Vessels of great burden can come up to this Quay, but the largest ships generally lie a few miles lower down : a very flourishing commerce with England, and other countries, is the happy consequence of sucb a situation. The principal articles of Export are beef, pork, butter, grain, and linen. Packet-boats are also established between this Port, and Milford Haven in South Wales, for the convenience of the South of Ireland. As tliere is no bridge over the Suir below Carrick, the only communication with the County of 4 u

WAT Kilkenny is by a Ferry, an inconvenience to which the great depth and breadth osthe ri\'er has hitherto compelled the inhabitants to submit. This city is about twelve miles distant from the Sea : The harbour runs almost tAvelve miles up the country, nearly in a straight line, and is all the way deep and clear. Here are several Charity Sehools, and Humane Foundations, well supported: Many of the public edifices are extremely elegant : Tbe private dwellings are generally modern, and Avith the other improvements of the city, keep pace Avith the increase of its opulence. It gives title of Viscount to the family of Lumley, that of Earl to the family of Talbot, and that of Marquess to the Earl of Tyrone. The See of Water ford (which is Aralued in the King's Books at £.72.. 8.. 1 Irish Money,) was united, according to Dr. Beaufort, in tbe year 1536, to the See of Lismore : The Bishoprick of Lismore had been founded in tlie beginning of the Seventh century ; but that of Waterford Avas not established until the Eleventh, Avhen the Ostmen or Danes settled on the Irish Coast. This very small Diocese is confined to the Eastern part of the County of Waterford, ancl does not extend above 10 miles in length, ancl 7 miles m breadth. But the Diocese of Lismore is 30 miles long, and about 29 miles broad, including the greatest part of the County of Waterford, and a considerable portion of tbat of Tipperary. The Union stretches in length 39- miles from East to West, and 29 miles in breadth. The Chapter of Waterford consists only of the Dean, Precentor (see, Kilbarrymeaden), Chancellor (see, Monemointer), and Treasurer (see, Lisnakill), for there are no Prebendaries, and the Archdeacon has not a vote. The Cathedral of Waterford is a very elegant church, erected Avithin a feAV years. Tbe Bishop's Palace, Avliich stands close by it, is a handsome modern structure of no great size, and very much confined in situation, — " The Priory of St. Catherine is the first House of Religion Avhich appears ; it Avas founded by the Ostmen for Augustinian Canons of the Congregation of St. Victor, but Ave know not at Avhat period. — The Hospital of St. Stephen, in St. Stephen's Street, was founded for Lepers, and endowed by the Power family. This Hospital must have been erected before tbe Benedictine Abbey, for John Earl of Morton, in his Charter to that Abbey, confirmed the Leper-House to the Poor of the City.— John Earl of Morton arrived in Waterford, A. D. 1185, when he founded the Priory of St. John the Evangelist in the suburbs of the City, for Monks of the Order of St, Benedict, and confirmed to them the lands of Ballyowedin. In the Charter he calls it his Alms-House, and makes it a Cell to the Abbey of St. Peter and St Paul in the City of Bath, Somersetshire. Peter de Fonte Avas a munificent Bene factor to this House.— The Friars Preachers, or Dominicans, were introduced into this city, A.D. 1226. And upon application of the Citizens to King Henry III, on the 20th of February, he granted his Royal approbation, that their intend ed house should be built on that waste piece of ground, late the site of an ancient tower. The building, Avas accordingly begun, and concluded. The steeple was a very strong building, and the Monastery (of St. Saviour), noAv the County

WES Court-house, is called Black Friars. — A Friary Avas founded, in 1240, for Con ventual Franciscans by the Lord Hugh Purcel, who was interred in the same year, on the right hand of the High Altar. The steeple is still entire, and, with the rest of the Abbey, is constantly kept in repair. Here are several ancient Tombs, on one is the figure of a man in armour, in high relief, Avith a shield on his left arm, on which are three Lions passant guardant in pale, but no inscription (this Avas the monument of the Founder). The Holy Ghost Hospital has been since erected on part of the ruins of the Friary." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. pp. 698. et seq. WATERGRASS-HILL, in the Barony of Barrymore, Co. of Cork, and Province of Munster. It is 5 m. S. b. W. from Rathcormuck. WATER- PARK, in the Barony of , Co. of Cork, and Province of Munster. It gives title of Baron to the family of Cavendish. WATTLE BRIDGE, in the Barony of Coole, Co. of Fermanagh, and Prov ince of Ulster. It is 9f m. N. from Cavan. It is situate on the River Fina. Here are the ruins of a Temple of the Druids. WEEME, within the County of the City of Cork, and Province of Munster. According to Mr. Archdall, there was an Abbey here for Canons Regular following the Rule of St. Augustin, which Avas dedicated to St. John the Evangelist WELLS, in the Barony of Idrone, Co. of Carlow, and Province of Leinster: a R., Avith the Chapel of Ballynockan, being the Corps osthe Deanery of Leigh lin, Avhich is valued in the King's Books at £5. .6.. 8 Irish Money: no Church, but one intended to be built, and iioav waiting for a new site : no Glebe House : six Glebes; the first, containing 2 roods; the second, 2 a. Or. 10 p.; the third, 3 a. 2 r. Op. ; the fourth, Oa. Sr. 1 p. ; the fifth, la. 2 r. 22 p.; these being nearly contiguous ; the sixth Glebe contains 12a. Or. 30 p., being two miles distant from the rest, another parish intervening : The Rev. George Maunsell, A. M., the Dean (in 1806), who has cure of souls, is resident, and discharges the duties, assisted by his Curate, The Rev. Mr. Vigers, at a Salary of £.10. Wells is in the Diocese of Leighlin, and Province of Dublin. It is 2 m. S. b. W. from Leighlin- Brid-re. It is situate near the River Barroxv. The Fairs are holden on Ascension- . ■-- n day and llth of December. The Deanery contains a part osthe parish of Old Leio-hlin, ancl the entire parish of Wells. WESTMORESTOWN, in the Barony of NeAvcastle, Co. of Dublin, and Province of Leinster : a V., being one of the parishes which constitute the Union of Leixlip. WestmorestOAvn is in the Dioceses of Dublin and Glandelagh, and Province of Dublin. See, Leixlip. WESTPALSTOWN, in the Barony of Balruddery, Co. of Dublin, and Prov ince of Leinster: a Curacy, being one osthe parishes which constitute the Union of Clonmethon. WestpalstoAvn is in the Dioceses of Dublin and Glandelagh, and Province of Dublin. It is 12 m. N. from Dublin. See, Clonmethon.

W E X WESTPORT, in the Barony of Morisk, Co. of Mayo, and Province of Con naught; in the parish of Aughaval. It is 123 m. W. N W. from Dublin. The Fairs are holden on the 1st of January, 25th of May, 6th of August, and 1st of December. It is situate on the Eastern extremity of Newpirt or Clew Bay. It has six Post-days in the Aveek. It is rapidly increasing in the Linen trade, by settlers from the Northern parts of Ireland : encouraged by the very neat cottages, and gardens, and other liberal inducements, provided for them by the present Noble owner. WEXFORD, within the Liberties osthe same, Co. of Wexford and Prov- * > ince of Leinster : a Corporate ToAvn, in which are the folloAving parishes, viz., St. Iberius, a Rectory Impropriate. St. Mary's, a Rectory and Vicarage ; the Rectory is valued in tbe King's Books at £.26.. 13. .4 Irish Money; and the Vicarage at £15..3..8. St. Michael's of Feagh, an Impropriate Cure, valued in the King's Books at £2. Irish Money. St. Patrick's, a Rectory, valued in the King's Books at £.20. Irish Money. St. Selskar, an Impropriate Cure. StvTullogue, an Impropriate Cure. all united Episeopally (except St. Patrick's), ever since 1732, to the R. ofBally brenan, and the Impropriate Cures of Carrigg, St. John's, and St. Peter's ; and united by Act of Council (including St. Patrick's), in 1772, to the Rectories of Ardcandrish, Drinagh, Kildavan, Killalogue, MaudlintOAvn, and Rathaspeck : a Church, in repair, in the parish of St. Iberius ; and a Church, at Rathaspeck, also in repair : a Glebe House, in the ToAvn of Wexford, and seAreral very small, and un productive Glebes therein, and in the suburbs : tAvo Glebes (but no Glebe House), at Rathaspeck ; the first, of about 5 acres, near the church ; the second, of about 3 acres : these glebes are distant about half a mile from each other : The Rev. John Elgee, the Incumbent (in 1806), Avho has cure of souls, is resident, ancl dis charges the duties, assisted by his Resident Curate, The Rev. Ralph Boyd, at a Salary of £75. per annum. Wexford is in the Diocese of Ferns, and Province of Dublin. It is 67 m. S. b. W. from Dublin. The Fairs are holden on the 17th of March, 1st of May, 29th of June, 2d of August, and 1st of November. This ToAvn sends one Member to Parliament; Patronage, in the families of Neville ancl Le Hunte. It is governed by a Mayor, Mayor osthe Staple, Recorder, tAvo Bailiffs, and a Town Clerk ; and gives title of Earl, as does Waterford also, to the family of Talbot, Earl of Shrewsbury in Great Britain. It is situate upon the River Slaney, Avhich empties itself into the Ocean here. The, Haven is large, but it is a Bar Harbour, and no vessels can go to the town, that draw above 10 feet water ; but must load and unload in a Creek, near the mouth of the Haven, 011 the South side, about three miles from Wexford, where there is a sufficiency of water, but no 2

W II I shelter from the South-Avest Avinds. The entrance of the Haven is defended by two Forts ; that on the North side, being called Fort Margaret, and the other, on the South, Fort Roselair. Provisions of all kinds are very plentiful and cheap here ; particularly the finest Wild Fowl, from tbe month of November to May. It was called by the Danes, avIio built it, Wessford, and also Carman, and was formerly a place of more strengtli and trade than at present. Its chief export is Corn, particularly Barley ancl Malt. Here is a Mineral Well. The parishes in the Union of Wexford are all contiguous, except Ballybrenan, Avhich is disunited by the intervention of the parish of Killenick, for the space of two miles : their con- tents are 7193 acres : the net value of the Union being £470. It has six Post-days in the Aveek : And is the Shire and the Assizes Town for the County. The first forces from England, which attempted the Conquest of Ireland, landed here. In the Barony of Forth, adjoining to Wexford, are said to be tbe remains of an ancient Colony, Avhich Avas planted there by King Henry the Second. These people retain their native language, manners, and many singular customs to this day. They in- termarry among themselves, and have intermixed little or none Avith the natives. They are remarkably industrious, cleanly to an extreme, and possessed of great simplicity of manners. — " A Priory of Regular Canons, called also Tbe Priory of St. Peter and St Paul of Selsker; the Danes are said to have been the founders, and the family of Roche, the Patrons of the place, Avere munificent Benefactors. The Prior sat in Parliament as a Baron. The church yet remains Avith a very large towrer in the centre. — The Priory of the Knights Hospitallers, founded by William Marescbal Earl of Pembroke, and dedicated to St. John and St Brigid, was, antecedent to the Templars' abolition, the grand Commandery ; but on the total suppression of those Knights, the consequence of this Priory gradually dimin- ished, and the Preceptory of Kilmainham being granted to the Hospitallers, it immediately became the Grand Commandery of their Order. There still remains part of the old church of St. John Avithout the town Avails. — The Conventual Fran- ciscans procured a settlement for themselves in this toAvn in the reign of King Henry III, ancl were reformed A. D. 1486.— Here Avas also an Hospital for Lepers." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. pp. 755. et seq. WHALEY ABBEY, v. BALLYKINE. WHERY, v. F1RBANE. WOLSTAN'S, ST., in the Barony of Salt, Co. of Kildare, ancl Provinceof Leinster. It is 2 m. S. W. from Leixlip. — '_■ A Priory Avas founded here in the year 1202, for Canons of the Order of St. Victor, by Adam de Hereford, in honour of St. Wolstan, Bishop of Worcester, then neAvly canonized. Richard was the first Prior, to whom de Hereford granted the lands on the River Liffey, and the church of Donaghcumper. At the suppression of Religious Houses, it Avas granted to Allen of Norfolk, Master of the Rolls, in the year 1538, and aftenvards Lord Chancellor : in whose family it continued to the year 1752, when, by a Decree of the Court of Exchequer, it was sold, and purchased by Dr. Robert Clayton, Bishop of Clogher, by whom it was bequeathed to his niece Anne, wife to Dr. Thomas Bernard, Bishop of Killaloe. The present House Avas built by one of the Aliens, a man Avell known for his skill in architecture; he planned the noble House at SigginstoAvn, in this County, intended for the unfortunate Earl of Stafford : con siderable alterations and additions have been made here by The Right Reverend OAvner, and St. Wolstan's is noAv an elegant edifice. The ancient Priory Avas of a considerable extent ; but now there only remain two towers and tAvo large gateAvays arched." — ArchdaWs Monast. Hibern. p. 339.
